cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 6:9

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information
No Improper Use or Disclosure of the Information

para.paratext: It is a full defence to state that there was no improper use or disclosure of confidential information or that such use or disclosure is unlikely to occur. No improper use occurs if a party uses secret information only for the purposes for which it was communicated.

In Craig v. CEO Global Network Inc.,[1] CEO Global was in the business of providing professional consulting services to corporate executives through group mentoring, expert speaker programs and executive coaching. Wilson carried on that business previously with a competitor, TEC Canada, where he worked with the Plaintiff Craig. After Wilson established CEO Global, he invited Craig to join. Craig became the executive vice-president of CEO Global. The Consulting Agreement he signed provided for a one-year term that would automatically renew on its anniversary date subject to rights of early termination. Part way through the second term, CEO Global provided sixty days' notice to Craig of termination of the Consulting Agreement. CEO Global agreed to pay Craig six months' compensation additional to the sixty days' notice, consistent with its interpretation of the Consulting Agreement's provision for termination without cause. CEO Global paid Craig the first month of notice, but then did not pay the second month of notice or the six months of additional compensation. CEO Global's lawyer notified Craig that CEO Global was discharged from making any further payments to him because it discovered that he had breached the non-competition provision contained in the Consulting Agreement, thereby entitling CEO Global it to terminate the Consulting Agreement for cause.[2]

On March 29, 2019, Craig produced to CEO Global a confidential client and prospective client list that he had downloaded from the CEO Global computer system four days after he was provided with notice of termination but before the expiry of the sixty-day notice period. He also produced a copy of CEO Global's Strategic Plan created on February 4, 2011 that he had retained. At the start of the closing submissions at trial, CEO Global amended its statement of defence to plead that it was entitled to terminate the Consulting Agreement with cause by reason of Craig's breach of the confidentiality provision of the Consulting Agreement and his breach of the duty of honesty and good faith that he owed to CEO Global in the performance of the contract. CEO Global did not tender any evidence of any harm, or detriment of any nature, resulting from Craig having had confidential documents in his possession in the more than seven years that had passed since termination. The trial judge concluded that CEO Global failed to establish just cause for its termination of the Consulting Agreement. The Plaintiff was entitled to judgment against CEO Global of $150,899, plus pre-judgment interest.[3]

CEO Global contended that it was justified in terminating Craig for cause on the basis that he materially breached the Non-Competition Provision. The burden of establishing that the Non-Competition Provision is lawful and enforceable is on the party seeking its enforcement. The general principle applied in most common law jurisdictions is that “non-competition clauses in employment contracts are void” because a non-competition provision in an employment contract is a restraint of trade, and restraints of trade are contrary to public policy considerations because they interfere with individual liberty of action. The Supreme Court has stated that restrictive covenants are enforceable only when they are reasonable. The onus is on the party seeking to enforce the restrictive covenant to establish that its terms are reasonable. The Supreme Court of Canada has drawn a distinction between restrictive covenants contained in commercial contracts and in contracts pertaining to employment, noting that different considerations are pertinent to each. In particular, in the employment setting there may be an imbalance in power between the parties to the employment contract. The reasonableness test for assessment of a restrictive covenant has been found to be applicable to independent contractor relationships as to employer-employee relationships.[4]

The trial judge was of the view that there were three factors that rendered the Non-Competition Provision unreasonable. First, the Consulting Agreement contained a Non-Solicitation Provision, which prohibited Craig from soliciting, enticing or accepting work from Members and Prospective Members of CEO Global. The trial judge did not consider that this was an exceptional case, where CEO Global reasonably required a Non-Competition Provision for the protection of its business once it already had in place the Non-Solicitation Provision that covered both Members and Prospective Members for one year. The Non-Competition Provision would foreclose Craig from advancing his own business to service clients over whom CEO Global has not asserted any proprietary interest. Also, Craig contracted to serve CEO Global as an independent contractor, which implied that he would operate independently and that his business would provide service to more than one client. The Non-Solicitation Provision was sufficient to reasonably protect the interests of CEO Global, such that the Non-Competition Provision was void on this basis alone.[5]

Second, an ambiguous restrictive covenant is prima facie unreasonable. The ambiguity in the Non-Competition Provision was its prohibition that Craig could not engage in or carry on a “business similar to the business” carried on by CEO Global. This presented an ambiguity in the scope of the Non-Competition Provision that was made obvious by the disproportionate amount of trial time expended in debate concerning whether Craig's provision of one-on-one executive coaching was a “business similar” to that conducted by CEO Global. The “use of the words ‘or a business similar thereto’ introduces a massive breadth of possible interpretations and hence introduces great uncertainty and ambiguity into the clause”. The business of CEO Global in providing professional consulting services to corporate executives was already broad in scope, and the use of the term “business similar” broadened the provision so vastly that it became ambiguous and could not be reasonable.[6]

Third, CEO Global had not established that the geographic scope of the Non-Competition Provision, being “the geographic area of Canada and the United States in which the Client carries on business”, was reasonable. The reasonableness of a restrictive covenant must take into consideration the “extent of the activity sought to be prohibited and the extent of the temporal and spatial scope of the prohibition”. CEO Global sought to restrain the business of Craig as an independent contractor in the entirety of Canada and the United States for a year. There must be a rational basis for the breadth of its reach in order to be reasonable, and that had not been established. The trial judge concluded that the geographic scope of the restrictive covenant was unreasonable because its scope was broader than necessary to protect the interests of CEO Global.[7]

The Confidentiality Provision stated that Craig agreed to keep in strictest confidence all confidential information that he received while with CEO Global, and not to publish, communicate, disclose or use any such information. CEO Global submitted that Craig materially breached the Confidentiality Provision because he obtained and kept in his possession confidential documents.[8]

The Plaintiff emphasized that the Client List was a “valuable document” that contained both actual clients and prospective clients, referred to as “leads”. The company paid for certain of the leads and so had a monetary investment in the development and protection of the Client List. The Client List would be very valuable to a competitor. Craig also kept other confidential documents, such as the Business Plan and the Competitor Comparison Chart. Craig admitted that the Client List was a “highly confidential document” that was, throughout, the property of CEO Global. He conceded, as well, that the Business Plan was proprietary information belonging to CEO Global, as was the Competitor Comparison Chart. Craig provided an explanation for printing the Client List after receiving notice of termination. He stated that he printed the Client List in furtherance of the discussions that were underway wherein it was proposed that Craig would continue to provide sales and marketing consulting services. Craig stated that he printed the Client List during these discussions to guide his assessment of the nature of the ongoing role that he would have with CEO Global, to help him understand the current leads and consider further leads that he could identify and present to CEO Global. This explanation addressed why he printed the Client List but did not account for why he did not return it when all discussions of a post-termination relationship ended between Craig and CEO Global. Craig swore that he did “absolutely not” ever use the Client List or the Business Plan or any other confidential information belonging to CEO Global. Indeed, he testified that he did not even recall that he had the documents until conducting a search of documents material to CEO Global for the purpose of trial.[9]

The trial judge accepted Craig's explanation that he printed the Client List to understand the remaining sector of leads that he could target for presentation to CEO Global apart from those already listed as prospects on the Client List because the timing of the printing of the list coincided with the discussions then-underway between the parties and because the information formed part of the ongoing analysis required by those discussions. CEO Global did not lead any evidence that it had sustained any damage, or any harm of any nature, by reason of Craig's possession of the Confidential Documents. CEO Global did not lead any evidence that Craig used or disclosed any of the Confidential Documents, at all.[10]

CEO Global was required to establish that the breach of the Confidentiality Provision was substantial, serious and consequential in nature in the context of the relationship between the parties. The trial judge did not condone Craig's failure to return the Confidential Documents after the effective date of termination of the Consulting Agreement. Craig breached section 4(e) of the Consulting Agreement. However, this duty matured, and the resultant breach of duty occurred “upon the termination” of the Consulting Agreement. As such, this breach on the part of Craig did not qualify as after-acquired cause, because it was not conduct that occurred prior to effective termination of the employment contract. To seek a remedy from Craig for conduct that occurred post-termination, whether in the nature of failure to return documents or competing with CEO Global post-termination, CEO Global was required to do so by way of set-off in its statement of defence or by way of counterclaim.[11]

The trial judge did not condone Craig printing the Client List without the express permission and not returning it to CEO Global upon termination or, indeed at any time prior to the days before trial. However, to constitute a material breach of the Confidentiality Provision sufficient to constitute just cause for termination, CEO Global was required to establish more. CEO Global was required to establish that Craig: (a) breached his obligation to keep the confidential information in the “strictest of confidence”; or (b) breached his obligation “not to publish, communicate or disclose to any unauthorized third party any such information”. Whether confidential information was misused, and if so how, is a factual determination to be made on a case-by-case basis. A detailed evaluation must be made of the actions of the former employee or contracting party. CEO Global did not lead any evidence that Craig failed to keep the Confidential Documents in confidence or that he, in any manner, published, communicated or disclosed to anyone any of the Confidential Documents. Craig throughout seven years kept the Confidential Documents in confidence and had not published, communicated or disclosed to anyone any of the Confidential Documents. The trial judge accepted Craig's evidence on his treatment of the Confidential Documents. CEO Global did not lead any evidence, at all, that contradicted Craig's sworn testimony, which was unshaken by cross-examination, that he had not used or disclosed the Confidential Documents. CEO Global had no evidence that, at any time over the last seven years, it had gained any knowledge, or any indication in its market sector, that would cause it to conclude that any Confidential Documents had been disclosed or used by Craig. There was no evidence that Craig's current business activities had in any way built upon or applied the Confidential Documents. Indeed, Craig's business activities over the last number of years did not impact CEO Global sufficiently to cause CEO Global to even plead that Craig had used its confidential information. It was only Craig's very late return of the Confidential Documents that caused CEO Global to seize upon this issue, and not any experience by CEO Global that would lead it to suspect that Craig had misused its confidential information.[12]

CEO Global submitted that “possession” of confidential information is equivalent to “use” of confidential information, so that Craig's admitted “possession” of the Confidential Documents was sufficient to support a finding that he materially breached the Confidentiality Provision. CEO Global did not present a single case authority in support of this submission. The trial judge concluded that the Confidentiality Provision was not breached by possession of confidential information that was not used. The trial judge concluded that a breach of the Confidentiality Provision, in the context of the Consulting Agreement and the relationship between the parties, required more than Craig's possession of Confidential Documents. It required also a finding that Craig used the Confidential Documents in a way that the Confidentiality Provision did not permit.[13]

In Furfari v. Pedias,[14] the Plaintiff claimed that the defendant entered his home while he was on vacation and took some confidential documents and sought damages totaling $300,000, including aggravated and punitive damages. The Defendant's motion to strike the claim on the basis that the claim did not plead the necessary elements and material facts to support the claim for breach of confidence, and that the claim for aggravated was not properly pleaded was allowed.[15]

The Plaintiff and the Defendant had been friends until recently. The Plaintiff was also friends with the Defendant's brother, Mario. The claim was very short and made the following allegations of fact against the Defendant:

1. The Plaintiff owns a farm located in King City, Ontario (“Property”). The Plaintiff from time to time would hire the Defendant to carry out a variety of handyman type projects at the Property, including installation and maintenance of internet service and security systems.
2. The Defendant was thus familiar with the Property and enjoyed unsupervised access to it for purposes of the projects given to him by the Plaintiff but for no other purpose.

3. The Defendant understood and agreed that the Plaintiff granted him access to his private property on the basis of the Defendant's undertaking and promise of confidence and the Defendant's promise to protect and maintain the Plaintiff's privacy at all times.

4. On or about May 2018 when the Plaintiff was out of the country and without his knowledge or authorization, the Defendant alone or in concert with others gained access to the Property and removed personal and confidential papers, documents and records of the Plaintiff relating to his personal, financial and banking affairs (“Removed Items”).
5. Mario was aware that the Plaintiff was out of the country during this time.
6. The actions by the Defendant were unauthorized and were taken without lawful authority or excuse and without colour of right.
7. To the knowledge of the Defendant and Mario, taking of the Removed Items from the Property and any use to which they could be put would be unauthorized by the Plaintiff as well as unlawful.
8. Also to the knowledge of the Defendant, dissemination of the Removed Items to anyone would be detrimental to the Plaintiff and his personal and financial interests.[16]

Following the service of the statement of claim, the Defendant made a demand for particulars, including a request that the specific documents removed be identified. In response, the Plaintiff did not provide any particulars, in some cases on the grounds that no further particulars were available and in other cases that the request was not the proper subject of a demand for particulars.[17]

A claim for breach of confidence requires a plaintiff to prove three following elements including that a. the information was confidential; b. the information was conveyed in confidence; and c. the confidential information was misused by the party to whom it was communicated to the detriment of the confider. The Defendant argued that the statement of claim did not properly plead the first and third elements of the claim for breach of confidence. With respect to the first element, he argued that the claim did not sufficiently identify the documents to establish that they were confidential. With respect to the third element, he argued that there was no pleading that the information was misused in a way that caused damage to the Plaintiff.[18]

While the motions judge concluded that the first element was sufficiently pleaded, the motions judge agreed that the last element was not properly pleaded. With respect to the first element, the requirement is that the information be confidential. In this case, the claim described the documents as “personal and confidential papers, documents and records of the Plaintiff relating to his personal, financial and banking affairs”. While the claim did not identify the specific documents allegedly taken, they were described as “confidential” and as including financial and banking information, which is information typically considered as confidential. In the motions judge's view, this was sufficient for the purposes of pleading the first element of the tort of breach of confidence.[19]

With respect to the third element, the claim did not plead that the information was misused by the defendant to the Plaintiff's detriment. In Lysko v. Braley, the Court of Appeal noted that the concept of “detriment” in the context of a claim for breach of confidence is broad enough “to include the emotional or psychological distress that would result from the disclosure of intimate information”. However, there was no pleading that the Defendant misused the information to the Plaintiff's detriment. For example, there was no pleading that the information was conveyed to a third party and that the disclosure had a detrimental effect on the Plaintiff. Instead, the pleading on this point was entirely speculative, stating that the Defendant knew that “dissemination of the Removed Items to anyone would be detrimental to the Plaintiff and his personal and financial interests”.[20]

The motions judge concluded that the Plaintiff should be given an opportunity to remedy the deficiencies in the claims for breach of confidence and for aggravated damages. This was not a case where the claim was so deficient that it could not be remedied or where the Plaintiff had already been given an opportunity to amend his claim.[21]

In CTT Pharmaceutical Holdings v. Rapid Dose Therapeutics,[22] the Defendant moved for summary judgment on the basis that there was no evidence in support of the Plaintiff's claim. The principals of the Plaintiff had experience with manufacturing pharmaceuticals and the principals of the Defendant had experience in marketing various products. The parties entered an Asset Purchase Agreement pursuant to which the Defendant was to purchase the Plaintiff's assets. These consisted primarily of two patents relating to oral thin, dissolvable strips. The parties proposed joining efforts to market oral dissolvable strips impregnated with cannabis, which they planned to introduce as a new product on the Canadian market once the legislation legalizing the possession, sale, and consumption of cannabis came into force. At some point during its due diligence exercise the Defendant apparently concluded that the Plaintiff's technology was ineffective for the desired use. The parties had a mutual falling out, and the Plaintiff issued a formal notice to the Defendant terminating the Asset Purchase Agreement.[23]

The Plaintiff alleged that there were three areas of confidential information on which the claim was particularly focused: a) the identity of ODF Pharma, b) the identity of HED International, and c) patent applications prepared by the Plaintiff which had not yet been laid open to the public. The Plaintiff claimed that the Defendant misused confidential information by entering into a distribution agreement with HED International Inc. for tape casting machines. These devices supposedly allow for oral thin film to be imbued with chemical products such as cannabis extract, and the agreement permitted the Defendant to make them available to licensed Canadian producers of cannabis products. The Defendant's position was that HED International was well-known for this technology and that there was nothing proprietary about the Plaintiff's knowledge of this fact and thus nothing confidential about the passing on of this knowledge. Whether or not that was the case, the Defendant's affiant deposed that the HED International machines turned out not to be effective for cannabis-imbued oral strips and so the distributorship agreement never got off the ground. The Defendant thus incurred no gain and the Plaintiff suffered no loss. There was no evidence in the record to suggest anything to the contrary. Justice Morgan noted that the courts have observed that for a breach of confidence claim to succeed there must be actual evidence of financial loss. The goal of the remedy in this type of action is to restore the Plaintiff to the position it was in prior to the breach. Failure to prove an actual loss is failure to prove the grounds for a remedy.[24]

In Cantol v. State Chemical,[25] the Plaintiff sued the Defendants alleging breach of fiduciary duty and breach of confidence. The Defendants Daniska and Hanick who had worked for the Plaintiff company that made and sold industrial and specialty chemicals both quit and started working for State. Hanick felt he had been treated poorly by the company and had been denied his commissions. He had been employed with the company for six years as a salesperson. Daniska too felt poorly treated and subject to threats made by the owner that if he did not make his sales he would be fired. Daniska had been a salesperson with the company for 34 years. Neither of the men had any enforceable restrictive covenants in their Employment Agreements with the Plaintiff.[26]

Justice Nakatsuru observed the law is quite settled that a fiduciary employee cannot solicit the employer's customers for a reasonable period of time after the end of their employment. If one is not a fiduciary employee, they are free to solicit like any other employee. The question of whether a fiduciary duty exists depends upon the individual facts of the case. The question is often cast this way: Is the degree of responsibility, dependency, and vulnerability strong enough to support the finding of a fiduciary status? The Plaintiff submitted that Daniska was effectively a part of management and he was a key employee. By the time he resigned, he was titled VP of Marketing. It was argued that Daniska was the head person in sales and product knowledge in a small company with few employees and an informal structure. Daniska, along with Hanick, represented the majority of the Plaintiff's gross sales in Canada. Given his longevity in the company and knowledge, Daniska was a primary source of knowledge about the Plaintiff's products and was responsible for training sales staff. It was submitted that the Plaintiff entrusted its relationship with its customers to Daniska who was the face of the company for them. Therefore, according to the Plaintiff, it was vulnerable to solicitation of its customers by Daniska upon his departure.[27]

Justice Nakatsuru concluded that Daniska was not a fiduciary employee. Clearly, the owner, who was the President, the only officer, the sole director, and majority shareholder was in charge. The owner was the only person who had access to the financial and the business plans for the Plaintiff, who hired and fired staff, and to whom all sales staff ultimately reported. The owner did not sell products or manage client relationships. However, salespeople would ask him for approval for volume discounts or free shipping for its customers. The Plaintiff had some active 700 clients in total. The owner testified that in Canada, outside of Quebec, Daniska serviced about 60% of the Plaintiff's clients while Hanick serviced the remaining 40%. Quebec-based clients, which represented about 30% of all clients, were handled by Simard and Gosselin. Simard reported to Gosselin who in turn reported to the owner.[28]

Having regard to the factual context and looking at the actual job that Daniska performed, Justice Nakatsuru concluded that he was a salesperson and explained that, of course, this finding was not determinative of the issue of whether he owed fiduciary obligations. However, it was an important factor. Justice Nakatsuru did not agree that based Daniska was effectively management.[29]

A claim for breach of confidence is made out when the information in question has the necessary quality of confidence about it, the information was imparted in circumstances importing an obligation of confidence, and there was an unauthorized use of that information to the detriment of the party communicating it. In this case, the Plaintiff acknowledged that it had no documentary evidence of any breach of confidence. There was no evidence that Daniska misappropriated or took any customer lists or physical files with him. Daniska returned everything to the owner when he left and did not make any copies. Daniska testified that he found contact information of former customers through the Internet or LinkedIn. He also made personal visits to customers he knew.[30]

However, the Plaintiff submitted that Daniska admitted to a breach of confidence in his examination for discovery. It argued that the purchasing habits of the Plaintiff's customers including the types of products, quantities, and prices paid, was confidential information. The Plaintiff pointed to the following answers given by Daniska as an admission that he used this confidential information to the detriment of the Plaintiff:
Q. … was there a situation where you noticed that the State product was more expensive?
A. In some cases State's products were more expensive, in some cases some of their products were … it depended on the product.
Q. Would you adjust prices so that they would be more competitive?
A. I could adjust prices, yes.
Q. And did you, for some customers, because Cantol products were cheaper?

A. Cantol products were cheaper … well, it depends on the … I mean, I can't recall. Yes, I adjusted certain prices for people but it depends. Some products weren't even related to Cantol products. You know, for example, one was a water treatment project, which Cantol doesn't even have, so that is … And I adjusted that price. So, I … you know, it depends on the customer.

Justice Nakatsuru concluded that the exchange was not the admission as alleged by the Plaintiff. On its face, Daniska did not admit that he used the Plaintiff's pricing information to price products more competitively. Daniska testified that he “could” adjust prices, not that he did do so. This ability to engage in competitive pricing depended on the product Daniska was dealing with, since some products were not even sold by the Plaintiff. Essentially, Daniska admitted he “could” have adjusted prices to make them more competitive, but he really could not recall any time he did. In Justice Nakatsuru's opinion, these answers were far too equivocal to base a factual finding that Daniska did in fact use confidential pricing information to advance the corporate defendant's interests. The Plaintiff did not secure an admission against interest during this part of its examination. Secondly, when this passage is placed in the context of the entirety of Daniska's examination for discovery and his affidavit where he adamantly denied ever using the Plaintiff's confidential information, Justice Nakatsuru found no support for the Plaintiff's argument that Daniska had admitted to a breach of confidence. Indeed, immediately before the cited passage, Daniska denied ever telling the corporate defendant about the volume of product the Plaintiff's customers used to purchase.[31]

Regarding the evidence against Hanick in his own capacity, there was even less reason to find him a fiduciary employee than Daniska. Further, the Plaintiff had no evidence that Hanick took or misused any confidential information. At its core, the Plaintiff's position was that he, like Daniska in many respects, solicited its clients, whose identity he came to know through working for the Plaintiff. In Justice Nakatsuru's view, this was not sufficient to ground a finding of breach of confidence.[32]

In OIBC v. KO,[33] Ko had worked for OIBC, an insurance brokerage in Richmond Hill owned and operated by husband and wife, Lau and Chik. Ko resigned saying she was tired and wanted to spend more time for herself after 23 years of service. Ko changed her mind the next day and contacted the defendant insurance brokerage to inquire about a job. She started actively working for them within one week. Overtime, a significant number of OIBC's clients transferred over to Ko.[34]

Justice Nakatsuru explained that he was not ignorant of the fact that the timing of the resignation and subsequent acceptance of employment at the defendant brokerage raised a red flag. However, while Justice Nakatsuru did not find Ko's explanation as to why she resigned and then started working at a competitor so quickly particularly compelling, he was satisfied that this did not raise an issue requiring a trial. The bottom line was that she moved quickly to a competitor. Her motivation for doing so was a factor to be considered and was something that could be considered properly on a summary judgment motion.[35]

Justice Nakatsuru concluded that Ko did not leave with the confidential information of OIBC. If wrong about this, summary judgment should still be given as Ko did not solicit OIBC's clients or otherwise misuse this confidential information.[36]

Almost immediately after Ms. Ko's resignation, the Plaintiff wrote letters to the clients that Ko had serviced advising them of her departure and the fact that Chik would take over their files. Then Ko wrote letters to the 242 clients in the contact list on her phone. These were generic form letters in English and Chinese. Justice Nakatsuru concluded that the letter and the actions of Ko did not constitute solicitation. Ko did not ask for anything. Numbers alone do not establish solicitation. Justice Nakatsuru concluded that a plausible and reasonable explanation for this transfer of business other than solicitation by Ms. Ko could well be her longstanding business and professional relationship with these clients built on mutual trust.[37]

In Brand Name Marketing Inc. v. Rogers Communications Inc.,[38] Justice Wilton-Spiegel concluded that Rogers did not appropriate or misuse any significant element or component of either the Pink Phone program or the Call for the Cure program in creating and implementing the Pink Razr campaign.[39]

The Pink Razr campaign had its origins in Motorola's decision to offer Rogers the exclusive opportunity to distribute, on a limited quantity basis, a new product that was intended to be attractive to younger women who were seen to be trendsetters. Rogers contributed to the marketing campaign the suggestion that Motorola use co-op marketing funds of $150,000 to make a $25 donation to Rethink for each handset sold. The Rethink donation was a means of obtaining favourable publicity in the market to assist in selling the handsets. Such free publicity was intended to be the principal marketing tool for the Pink Razr campaign. Rogers was not prepared to spend any of its money on the Pink Razr campaign, including paying an accrual fee or an airtime residual to Rethink. Accordingly, the only similarity between the proposals of the plaintiff and of the Pink Razr campaign of any significance was that each involved a donation to a breast cancer charity for each purchase of a cellphone.[40]

Justice Wilton-Siegel concluded that Rogers did not use the marketing concept proposed by the plaintiff. The concept of a donation to a breast cancer charity in connection with the sale of a product was a well-established marketing tool by 2005 and therefore did not constitute confidential information. The plaintiff was therefore required to establish that it communicated something more to Rogers that Rogers used in the Pink Razr campaign. Insofar as it was suggested that Rogers applied the plaintiff's marketing concept, the claim failed. The marketing concept proposed by the plaintiff was substantially different from the marketing concept that was implemented in the Pink Razr campaign. Three elements of the plaintiff's marketing concept were significant: (1) the focus on the sale of long-term airtime contracts; (2) the emphasis on the sale of such contracts, or extensions of existing contracts, to “loyalty” and “retention” customers, who were already existing Rogers customers; and (3) the reduced churn among Rogers' subscriber base and consequential lower cost of acquisition to Rogers of such contracts said to result from the affinity relationship, which would make the concept, as implemented by the Pink Phone or the Call for the Cure programs, profitable to Rogers. Justice Wilton-Siegel observed that none of these elements were part of the marketing concept underlying the Pink Razr campaign. The latter focused on the sale of a limited number of cellphones for image purposes to a target audience that was not part of Rogers' traditional customer base. Further, the marketing plan did not envisage any significant number of new customers joining the Rogers' network because of the affinity relationship with Rethink. In addition, any lowered cost of acquisition of airtime contracts resulted from Motorola's financial participation and the media-focussed marketing strategy, rather than the affinity relationship.[41]

There was also no evidence that Rogers used any of the plaintiff's information that was generated by the Survey. In particular, there was no evidence that Rogers used the plaintiff's estimate that implementation of the Call for the Cure program would reduce the churn rate for the Rogers' customer base by 0.28% monthly. Lin, on behalf of Rogers, assumed a 1.47% churn factor for cellphones purchased pursuant to the Pink Razr campaign in the financial projections that he prepared for the campaign. There was, however, no evidence that Lin ever saw the plaintiff's analysis, much less that Rogers ever accepted that analysis.[42]

With respect to the suggestion that the Survey provided an indication of consumer interest in the Pink Phone program which was useful to Rogers, this was not evidence that the Survey results were used by Rogers for the Pink Razr campaign. The Survey addressed a very different marketing program from the Pink Razr campaign. Rogers would not have relied on the Survey results in designing and implementing any marketing program along the lines of the Pink Phone program to which it might have committed.[43]

The extent to which Rogers used the plaintiff's information depended upon an assessment of the extent to which Rogers applied the Pink Phone program or the Call for the Cure program in conducting the Pink Razr campaign. Rogers clearly did not apply substantially all of either program in its conduct of the Pink Razr campaign. The points of commonality were limited to (1) the payment of an accrual fee of $25 per cellphone purchased; and (2) an affinity relationship with a breast cancer charity, as the recipient of the accrual fee by way of a $25 charitable contribution from Motorola, and certain dealers. These points of commonality represented, in the case of the Pink Razr campaign, the essence of the campaign but, in the case of the Pink Phone and the Call for the Cure programs, only one of four elements of the campaign.[44]

The Pink Razr campaign was a “narrow, manufacturer subsidized time limited promotion for a specific limited edition phone”. Essentially, the plaintiff's information all related to a different campaign. There was no information that the plaintiff communicated to Rogers that either provided a reason for the Pink Razr campaign or, in the case of the marketing activities, that would not otherwise have been applied in the design of such campaign. Rogers did not conduct the Pink Razr campaign for any purpose that was derived from information presented in the Pink Phone or the Call for the Cure programs. The object was not to secure new airtime contracts, to reduce the churn rate of existing customers, or to reduce the cost of acquisition of new or retention customers. It could not be said that there was any loyalty, retention or new acquisition component to the Pink Razr campaign. Further, there was nothing in any of the plaintiff's information that suggested that a stand-alone marketing program, entailing a one-time donation to a breast cancer charity would produce any of the benefits that the plaintiff suggested would have accrued to Rogers had it implemented the plaintiff's proposals. On their own terms, the Pink Phone and the Call for the Cure programs suggested that a marketing campaign based on a point-of-sale donation would not be successful unless it were incorporated into a much larger and continuing campaign focused on Rogers' existing customer base, and perhaps the particularly extensive network associated with the CBCF. The branded cellphone component of the Pilot Proposal was a very small contributor to both the projected number of airtime contracts contracted for, and the projected profitability of, the program. Moreover, both the Pilot Proposal and the Call for the Cure program relegated marketing to the branded cellphone segment of the market to a later phase.[45]

Justice Wilton-Spiegel observed that there was nothing unique or confidential in the marketing activities contemplated by the plaintiff in respect of the Pink Phone and the Call for the Cure programs. The marketing activities were presented at a general level. The plaintiff could not point to any particular marketing initiative that could be characterized as novel. In any event, the Pink Razr campaign was largely conducted using very different marketing activities from the activities contemplated by the Pink Phone and Call for the Cure programs.[46]

In Hamilton v. F&M Management Ltd.,[47] the essence of the plaintiffs' claim was that the defendants induced them to enter into a corporate services agreement and a non-disclosure agreement in order to obtain their confidential information and use it to develop, patent, and successfully market VECTTOR. The plaintiff Hamilton was an entrepreneur in the remediation industry. He was the principal of Enviro-Klean which produced a thermal desorption machine called the KM-4. F&M was a management firm that offered corporate advisory services to the waste management and remediation sectors. Calaeris was incorporated to build, develop, and sell a thermal desorption machine called VECTTOR. Bogzaran was a director of both F&M and Calaeris. His brother Ramin was a director of Calaeris but not of F&M. The plaintiffs retained F&M and entered into the agreements for that purpose.[48]

Prior to 2011, Hamilton had known Bogzaran for some time. Bogzaran became aware that Hamilton was considering selling his company and introduced him to his brother. The plaintiffs entered into the Agreements pursuant to which F&M was to assist in the sale of Enviro-Klean. In exchange for a fee, F&M would prepare a company profile based on confidential and other information received from the plaintiffs, identify potential buyers, and assist in the purchase process. Under the non-disclosure agreement, F&M did not require any rights in or licence to use confidential information received from the plaintiffs. It could only use that information for the purposes set out in these Agreements. The Agreements did not in any way restrict F&M or its principals from contracting with other thermal desorption companies, producers, or inventors to provide them with services similar to those in the Agreements or otherwise from engaging in any activities related to thermal desorption technology.[49]

Hoffman, who knew Bogzaran and had worked with him previously on a different thermal desorption process, developed VECTTOR. He deposed that he did so without the involvement of Bogzaran and that he received no information relating to this work from any of F&M, either of the Bogzaran brothers, or Banack, who was also a principal of Calaeris. Hoffman applied for a U.S. patent for VECTTOR on January 25, 2013, and for an international patent on January 24, 2014. Hamilton applied for Canadian and U.S. patents for the KM-4 on June 7, 2013.[50]

In April 2014, the International Patent Office issued a non-binding opinion indicating that the Hoffman process was patentable. On December 15, 2015, the U.S. Patent Office issued a non-final rejection of Hamilton's patent application on the basis that it was too similar to an existing patent. The similarity was not to the Hoffman process, but to another thermal desorption process.[51]

During his examination for discovery, Hamilton stated that the defendants used information that he had provided to them to help with the development of VECTTOR. However, despite being asked repeatedly to specify what that information was, he was evasive and unable to do so.[52]

In preparation for the litigation, the defendants commissioned an expert report from Sadler, a chemical engineer with experience and expertise in thermal desorption, incineration, air pollution control, and waste water treatment. He was provided with all of the material Hamilton had provided to F&M under the Agreements, as well as additional information provided by Hamilton to F&M and a CD containing videos of the KM-4. In his report, Sadler reviewed the patent applications filed in support of the KM-4 and VECTTOR, identifying in detail the similarities and differences between them, as well as novel features of each. He concluded that the Hoffman process was significantly different from the Hamilton process. The similarities between the two processes were not unique and had been employed on other processes. Sadler did not compare the KM-4 and VECTTOR machines in operation, because there was no KM-4 in operation that he could have observed.[53]

The defendants did not dispute that some of the information communicated by the plaintiffs to the defendants concerning the KM-4 was confidential. The Chambers judge observed that the question was whether there was any evidence that the defendants misused that information. Hoffman denied receiving any such information. The Chambers judge observed that while Sadler opined that some of the material delivered by the plaintiffs to F&M could be considered confidential and could be used to develop a process similar to that used in the KM-4, that Hoffman's process did not use those aspects of Hamilton's process. He also stated that the similarities between the two processes were not unique to them, but were also seen elsewhere in the thermal desorption industry. The Chambers judge concluded that the plaintiffs had not shown that it was more likely than not that F&M breached confidence by misusing information it received from the plaintiffs and disclosing it to Calaeris and/or Hoffman.[54]

In Catalyst Capital Group Inc. v. Moyse,[55] Catalyst claimed that West Face used confidential Catalyst information to successfully acquire an interest in WIND. Both Catalyst and West Face were investment management firms and had been competitors on potential deals including acquiring an interest in WIND. West Face was part of a consortium that acquired WIND. Catalyst had been a bidder for WIND and had an exclusive right for a period of time to negotiate a purchase. When Catalyst failed to conclude a purchase of WIND, West Face and its consortium partners acquired an indirect interest in WIND. Moyse was an analyst at Catalyst for a little under two years. He left Catalyst and worked at West Face for three and a half weeks. It was alleged that at some time between when Moyse first spoke to West Face and when he stopped working at West Face he gave West Face confidential information regarding Catalyst's strategy to acquire WIND that was used by West Face to structure its bid for WIND. Catalyst acknowledged that it had no direct evidence that Moyse provided confidential information to West Face regarding WIND. It submitted that an inference should be drawn that Moyse did so.[56]

Moyse was assigned to Catalyst's “core” telecommunications deal team and he prepared a pro-forma statement that showed a combined WIND and Mobilicity entity. Moyse collected data which was either publicly available or known to Catalyst, and then performed basic arithmetic to yield the final product. No knowledge of Catalyst's plans or strategy was required for Moyse to complete this assignment. Moyse's next contribution to Catalyst's telecommunications file occurred when Catalyst prepared a PowerPoint slide deck for a presentation to be made to Industry Canada. The PowerPoint was intended to be a framework for discussion with Government personnel. The PowerPoint outlined the existing regulatory environment and a number of options available to the Government, and the concessions that Catalyst believed would be required. Generally, the presentation set out three strategic options for the creation of a fourth national wireless carrier. Moyse's role was largely administrative. He was not involved in any discussions or debates to determine the content of the presentation. Moyse's contributions involved layout, data input and the creation of two tables based on publicly available information, one of which was the pro-forma which Moyse had prepared.[57]

Moyse received an oral offer and a written signed employment agreement with West Face following a number of interviews. During conversations between counsel, counsel to Catalyst informed counsel to West Face that Catalyst was particularly concerned about a specific transaction for which Catalyst and West Face had each submitted bids and identified this as a “telecom file”. The day after learning of Catalyst's concerns about a “telecom deal” and four days before Moyse began work at West Face, the Chief Compliance Officer at West Face erected a confidentiality wall with respect to WIND and Moyse. The confidentiality wall was disclosed to counsel for Catalyst the same day. Pursuant to the confidentiality wall Moyse was forbidden from communicating with anyone at West Face about the ongoing WIND negotiations, and vice-versa, and West Face's IT group restricted access to all WIND-related documents so that Moyse could not access them. Notification of the confidentiality wall and its terms was circulated to all relevant personnel at West Face including its four partners. The chief compliance officer telephoned Moyse to discuss the terms of restrictions he would be under. In the call, Moyse was told that he was not to talk about WIND with anyone at West Face, to ask anyone at West Face about WIND, to disclose to anyone at West Face any information about WIND or to attempt to access any of West Face's files regarding WIND. Moyse indicated that he would comply. West Face's head of technology confirmed that Moyse was excluded from the computer directory containing WIND related documents. Once Moyse began working at West Face, the West Face WIND deal team only met in private, behind closed doors, and away from the trading floor area where Moyse was seated.[58]

Equity will pursue confidential information that comes into the hands of a third party who receives it with knowledge that it was communicated in breach of confidence. Thus, if West Face received confidential information of Catalyst from Moyse and used it in its acquisition of its interest in WIND to the detriment of Catalyst, relief would be available to Catalyst. The first hurdle faced by Catalyst was to establish that West Face received any information from Moyse regarding Catalyst's involvement with WIND. Catalyst acknowledged that it could not point to any direct evidence to demonstrate that Moyse transferred Catalyst's confidential information concerning WIND to West Face. It submitted that the Court must look to the overall course of conduct of West Face to determine if it could be inferred that the transfer of confidential Catalyst information occurred. Catalyst made an elaborate argument that changes made in the strategy of West Face to acquire WIND that led to an offer without any condition requiring Government concessions could reasonably be explained by West Face having obtained the confidential Catalyst information from Moyse and that an inference should be made that there was a transfer of such confidential information by Moyse to West Face. The Court rejected this argument. There was direct evidence that Moyse did not impart any information about Catalyst's initiative with WIND to anyone at West Face. There was no reason not to accept the evidence of the other West Face witnesses who testified that Moyse never discussed WIND with them. The fact that West Face took pains to impress upon Moyse before he started at West Face that his obligations of confidentiality to Catalyst were to be respected and that it set up a confidentiality wall once it was made aware of Catalyst's concerns regarding a telecom file that Catalyst said both firms were working on is contrary to the notion that West Face was interested in acquiring information regarding Catalyst's involvement in WIND.[59]

There were reasons for West Face to make its bid that it did with the consortium other than acting on confidential Catalyst information obtained from Moyse. Regarding West Face's view that Catalyst was a bidder for WIND, there was sufficient information in the marketplace for West Face to put two and two together to believe or presume that Catalyst was a bidder. The Court would not infer that Moyse told West Face that Catalyst was a bidder for WIND. The persons at West Face involved in the deal believed Catalyst was a bidder without actually knowing that.

The inference which Catalyst asked to be drawn that West Face acquired from Moyse confidential Catalyst information about its interest and strategy to acquire WIND and about its regulatory strategy and that West Face passed that information on to its partners in the consortium would amount to several witnesses purposely giving false testimony. To the contrary, the Court found that Moyse never communicated to anyone at West Face, either in the interview process or later, anything about Catalyst's dealings with WIND or of Catalyst's regulatory or telecommunications industry strategy regarding its interest in WIND. On that basis, the action against West Face for breach of confidence failed.[60]

In light of the finding that no Catalyst confidential information was given by Moyse to West Face or passed on to the consortium members, it was not necessary to deal with the issue of whether West Face made use of any Catalyst confidential information in any detail. Assuming, without deciding, that some of the information said to have been passed on by Moyse to West Face was confidential, the Court would not find that West Face made use of it. The price of the bid by West Face and the consortium with an enterprise value of $300 million was based on what VimpelCom and its advisor had made clear to West Face and others as to the amount that VimpelCom required. Even if Moyse had known and told West Face of the intention of Catalyst to bid at an enterprise value of $300 million, West Face made no use of such information.[61]

The basic strategy of Catalyst was based on its belief that WIND could not survive without Government concessions that would allow WIND to sell its spectrum to an incumbent by the end of five years. Even had West Face or its consortium members been told of this strategy by Moyse, it played no part in the reasoning of West Face to bid as it did by itself and later with the consortium. West Face did not hold the same view regarding the need for concessions and held the view that so long as WIND would be able to acquire additional spectrum to upgrade its network from a 3G (third generation) wireless network to an LTE network, which was made clear by the Industry Canada announcement on July 4, 2014, WIND would be a viable business. The other consortium members held the same view. For the same reason, even if Moyse disclosed to West Face the views that the potential litigation by some other party against the Government would force the Government to grant concessions and that the Government was therefore softening its position on concessions, that disclosure played no part in the decision of West Face to make the bids that it did. West Face would never have based its strategy on the litigation that some unnamed party other than Catalyst would have pursued against the Federal Government over the regulatory restrictions that limited transferability of the 2008 spectrum licenses. West Face believed that the Government was going to continue to maintain the existing restrictions on transfers of spectrum to incumbents. West Face never understood the Government's policy stance to be a bluff. In summary, if Moyse provided to West Face any confidential Catalyst information, such information was not used by West Face in its acquisition from VimpelCom of its interest in WIND or of its later acquisition of its shareholding in WIND. For this reason too, the action for breach of confidence against West Face failed.[62]
The Ontario Court of Appeal dismissed Catalyst's appeal from the judgment dismissing the action in The Catalyst Capital Group Inc. v. Moyse.[63]

To succeed on the misuse of confidential information claim, Catalyst had to prove that: Moyse gave confidential information concerning Catalyst's bid to purchase WIND to West Face; West Face used that confidential information when pursuing its bid for WIND; and the misuse of that confidential information caused detriment to Catalyst. Catalyst did not have direct evidence to support its allegations. It relied on a body of circumstantial evidence.[64]

On the first issue, whether Moyse had provided confidential information about Catalyst's strategies in respect of the acquisition of WIND to West Face, Catalyst relied heavily on inferences it claimed should be drawn from Moyse's conduct while he was pursuing employment with West Face, immediately after he left Catalyst to join West Face, and after litigation was commenced. That evidence included the following: Moyse deliberately provided Catalyst's confidential information to West Face when he was trying to get a job with West Face. This information did not relate to WIND. Moyse erased emails that showed he provided that confidential information to West Face; Moyse erased all of the contents of the BlackBerry Catalyst had provided to him for work purposes before he returned it to Catalyst after he quit; Moyse made inaccurate and potentially misleading statements in affidavits filed on preliminary motions in the litigation; Moyse deleted his internet browsing history from his personal computer and installed programs to scrub the computer registry where deletions could otherwise be detected, in the face of a court order requiring that he turn his computer over to his lawyer so that the computer could be forensically examined for the purposes of this litigation. Catalyst claimed that Moyse's conduct was consistent only with him having provided confidential information about Catalyst's proposed acquisition of WIND to West Face.[65]

Moyse gave various “innocent” explanations for his conduct. West Face also led evidence that when Moyse was hired by West Face, extensive measures were taken to ensure that Moyse had no knowledge of, or involvement in, West Face's ongoing negotiations for the purchase of WIND shares. The witnesses testified that there were no breaches of this confidentiality wall during the few weeks that Moyse was actually present in the West Face offices.[66]

The respondents also introduced a body of evidence, which they claimed demonstrated that no confidential information from Catalyst had been used in the ultimately successful bid for WIND. The respondents argued that the approach taken by West Face and its consortium to the acquisition of WIND, particularly with respect to the need to obtain certain concessions from the government, was fundamentally different than the approach taken by Catalyst. Consequently, West Face had no use for any information pertaining to Catalyst's strategies.[67]

The respondents also defended on the basis that the appellant had not proved any damages. The respondents claimed that Catalyst's bid to acquire WIND in August 2014 failed, not because of any competing bid made by West Face and the consortium, but because Catalyst chose to terminate negotiations with the vendor of the WIND shares after the vendor demanded a significant break fee very late in its negotiations with Catalyst. The respondents contended at trial that the evidence showed that Catalyst chose to end the negotiations rather than agree to the break fee demanded by the vendor. On this argument, Catalyst suffered no damages or detriment, even if Moyse had given confidential information to West Face and West Face had attempted to use that information in its negotiations with the vendor of the WIND shares.[68]

The trial judge found against Catalyst on almost every contested factual issue. Specifically, he found that the appellant chose to terminate its negotiations with the vendor of the WIND shares when the vendor demanded a substantial break fee. The trial judge made strong credibility findings against the appellant's primary witnesses, and equally strong credibility findings in favour of the respondents' witnesses, including Moyse. The trial judge accepted the explanations offered by Moyse for his conduct. The trial judge found, as a fact, that Moyse had not provided any confidential information to West Face in relation to the appellant's negotiations for the purchase of the WIND shares.[69]

The appellant submitted that the trial judge's factual findings could not stand, first, because they were the product of an unfair and uneven scrutiny by the trial judge of the competing versions of the relevant events and, second, because they were tainted by several material misapprehensions of the evidence.[70]

The result was almost entirely fact-driven. The trial judge's findings of fact turned on his assessment of the credibility of the key witnesses, the reliability of their evidence, and the inferences to be drawn from certain primary findings of fact. All of those tasks engaged a myriad of considerations by the trial judge. His determinations were owed strong deference on appeal. The appellant was required to overcome that deference in the face of reasons by the trial judge that displayed a strong command of the evidentiary record and a full understanding of the issues and positions of the parties.[71]

In support of the uneven scrutiny argument, counsel submitted that the credibility of the Catalyst witnesses was subject to a hypercritical microscopic examination by the trial judge. Any misstep or inconsistency in their testimony, no matter how apparently minor, became, for the trial judge, a reason to reject the evidence of those witnesses. In contrast, the trial judge forgave or ignored similar, and much more serious, defects in the evidence of witnesses for the respondents.[72]

Counsel's submissions made a case for different credibility and reliability assessments than those made by the trial judge. However, that is not enough to warrant appellate intervention. It is not for an appellate court to consider what alternative findings may have been reasonably available on the trial record. The trial judge approached the evidence of the respondents' witnesses no differently than he did the evidence of the appellant's witnesses. Moyse's evidence that he did not provide confidential information concerning the WIND negotiations to West Face did not stand alone. The evidence found considerable, largely uncontradicted support in the testimony of the West Face witnesses. It also gained some inferential support in the trial judge's findings as they related to the West Face strategy in respect of the WIND negotiations, and the ultimate reason for the breakdown of the negotiations between the appellant and the vendor of the WIND shares. The trial judge was alive to the details of the evidence said to demonstrate Moyse's dishonesty and the unreliability of his evidence. The trial judge examined the evidence particularly as it related to the allegation that Moyse had deliberately deleted material from his personal computer and installed programming to hide that deletion and prevent any recovery of the material. In the end, the trial judge accepted Moyse's explanations for what he had done, and concluded that it could not be established that Moyse had actually used the programs he had installed on the computer to hide the deletions.[73]

The evaluation of the impact on credibility and reliability of specific inconsistencies and similar flaws in a witness's testimony lies at the very core of the trial judge's function. His conclusion that a certain inconsistency negatively impacted on the credibility of one witness, while a different inconsistency did not have the same negative impact on the credibility of a different witness testifying about an entirely different topic, did not, on its own, establish that the trial judge applied different levels of scrutiny to the evidence of those witnesses. Instead, it demonstrated that credibility and reliability assessments are fact and witness-specific.[74]

The Court of Appeal observed no misapprehension of any material facts by the trial judge. Most of the appellant's arguments failed because they did not reveal any misapprehension of the evidence, but instead revealed that the trial judge preferred the evidence of the respondents' witnesses and the inferences that flowed from that evidence over the competing evidence and inferences relied on by the appellant.[75]

In The Catalyst Capital Group Inc. v. VimpelCom Ltd.,[76] after its attempt to purchase Wind failed, Catalyst sued the respondents claiming more than $1 billion in damages. The motions judge dismissed the action on the basis of issue estoppel, cause of action estoppel, and abuse of process. The appeal was dismissed.[77]

Wind, a Canadian telecommunications provider, was owned by the respondents VimpelCom and Globalive. VimpelCom held the majority of the total equity and Globalive held the majority of the voting equity. Catalyst began negotiating with VimpelCom to purchase that interest. The respondent UBS advised VimpelCom in those negotiations. The negotiations gave rise to two agreements. Catalyst and VimpelCom negotiated a Confidentiality Agreement providing that the existence and content of their negotiations were confidential. Catalyst and VimpelCom signed an Exclusivity Agreement pursuant to which VimpelCom could negotiate only with Catalyst and could not solicit other bids. The exclusivity period under this agreement expired on August 18, 2014. By August 11, 2014, a deal seemed imminent. However, on this date, VimpelCom advised Catalyst that it wanted a $5 million to $20 million break fee and insisted on shortening the regulatory approval period for the deal from three months to two months. Catalyst refused to agree to these demands and ceased negotiations. The exclusivity period expired without a deal. After the exclusivity period expired, a group of purchasers successfully purchased VimpelCom's interest in Wind. The Consortium concluded the deal within a month of the exclusivity period's expiry. The Consortium had made an unsolicited purchase proposal to VimpelCom. VimpelCom did not respond to the proposal until the exclusivity period under its Exclusivity Agreement with Catalyst expired.[78]

Moyse, a junior analyst at Catalyst, left Catalyst and began working for West Face during the course of Catalyst's negotiations with VimpelCom. He resigned from Catalyst after the signing of the Confidentiality Agreement but before the conclusion of the Exclusivity Agreement. Catalyst commenced an action against Moyse and West Face to enforce the non-competition clause in Moyse's employment contract with Catalyst prior to the failure of Catalyst's bid to acquire Wind.[79]

Following the Consortium's purchase of VimpelCom's interest in Wind, Catalyst broadened the scope of the Moyse Action. It amended its statement of claim to allege that Moyse had communicated confidential information to West Face about Catalyst's acquisition strategy with respect to Wind. Catalyst alleged that West Face used the confidential information it received from Moyse to successfully acquire Wind from VimpelCom. Justice Newbould concluded that Catalyst had failed to make out each of the three elements of the breach of confidence claim. First, Moyse did not communicate any confidential information about Catalyst's acquisition strategy to West Face. Second, West Face made no use of such information in acquiring Wind. Third, even if West Face made use of Catalyst's confidential information, Catalyst suffered no detriment.[80]

Justice Tulloch observed that Justice Newbould's findings in the Moyse action on the detriment requirement of the breach of confidence cause of action were most relevant to this appeal. First, Justice Newbould found that it was Catalyst's failure to agree to the break fee that VimpelCom requested that caused Catalyst to cease negotiations with VimpelCom. Second, Justice Newbould found that there was “no chance” that Catalyst could have closed the deal with VimpelCom because Catalyst insisted on making the deal conditional on receiving regulatory concessions from Industry Canada, a condition VimpelCom was unwilling to agree to. The Court of Appeal dismissed Catalyst's appeal in the Moyse action.[81]

The respondents in the Current Action moved to dismiss Catalyst's claims. Following the Court of Appeal's dismissal of Catalyst's appeal in the Moyse Action, the motions judge released reasons dismissing Catalyst's claim. The motions judge dismissed the claim on the basis of issue estoppel and cause of action estoppel against VimpelCom and Globalive, as well as against Tennenbaum, 64NM LP, 64NM GP, and LG. While Globalive and the US Investors were not parties to the Moyse Action, the motions judge found that they were privies of West Face. The motions judge also dismissed Catalyst's claim against all respondents as an abuse of process. Finally, the motions judge struck Catalyst's claim of breach of contract against Globalive and UBS without leave to amend.[82]

Catalyst submitted that Justice Newbould's findings were in obiter and collateral because they were not necessary to his decision. For Catalyst, the central issue in the Moyse Action was whether Moyse passed confidential information to West Face and since Justice Newbould found that Moyse had not, his other findings were collateral. Justice Tulloch rejected this submission. Catalyst's submission was premised on the assumption that the only fundamental issue in the Moyse Action was whether Moyse passed confidential information to West Face. However, to succeed in its breach of confidence claim, Catalyst was also required to prove that West Face used confidential information in its bid for Wind and that this misuse caused detriment to Catalyst.[83]

Justice Tulloch noted that Canadian courts have consistently rejected the argument that a judicial finding is merely dictum or collateral because there was another sufficient basis for the judge's decision. Accepting Catalyst's argument would lead to absurd consequences, because it would make the applicability of issue estoppel dependent on the order in which the court chose to address issues in its reasons.[84]

Catalyst further submitted that Justice Newbould's findings were merely overlapping facts such that the same question was not determined. For Catalyst, the Moyse Action was about confidential information that Moyse received and transmitted. In contrast, Catalyst submitted that this action concerned the transmission of confidential information by VimpelCom and/or UBS to the Consortium in breach of the Confidentiality Agreement and the Exclusivity Agreement. As a result, it follows that Justice Newbould's finding that even if Moyse did pass on confidential information to West Face, and such confidential information did not cause detriment to Catalyst, it did not mean that confidential information that VimpelCom and/or UBS leaked to the Consortium did not cause detriment to Catalyst. Justice Tulloch did not accept this argument. It was premised on a misunderstanding of what the parties put at issue in the Moyse Action. The Moyse Action necessarily concerned the overall conduct of West Face and the other Consortium members. As Catalyst had no direct evidence that Moyse gave West Face confidential information, it submitted that the court should infer from all the evidence that he did so. As Justice Newbould recognized, this required the court to examine West Face's “overall course of conduct” to determine if there was a transfer of Catalyst's confidential information or if there were other explanations for West Face's conduct. Therefore, whether West Face received any confidential information in breach of the Confidentiality Agreement and the Exclusivity Agreement, and whether West Face's use of confidential information caused any detriment to Catalyst, were live issues at trial. Justice Newbould was thus required to analyze whether the conduct of West Face and other Consortium members was consistent with the use of confidential information and whether there was any evidence that the use of confidential information caused Catalyst a detriment. He was entitled to draw inferences from the evidence as to what would likely have happened but for a misuse of confidential information. As the motions judge noted, West Face invited Justice Newbould to make findings of fact that Catalyst failed to acquire Wind because it refused VimpelCom's demand for a break fee and because it would have been unable to obtain regulatory concessions. Catalyst did not object to any of these proposed findings of fact as being outside of the scope of the Moyse Action. In fact, Catalyst elicited considerable evidence on the dealings between VimpelCom and UBS, and the Consortium, and urged Justice Newbould to make certain findings in respect of these dealings. Catalyst could not now complain that it was improper for Justice Newbould to make contrary findings or that those contrary findings were not essential to his decision. Justice Tulloch did not accept Catalyst's argument that Justice Newbould's findings on detriment were restricted to detriment from confidential information transmitted by Moyse. Catalyst chose to put at issue not only the Consortium's entire conduct, but also the reasons why Catalyst failed to acquire Wind and whether misuse of confidential information by the Consortium had anything to do with that failure. Justice Newbould did not overstep his bounds in finding against Catalyst on these issues.[85]

Catalyst submitted that Justice Newbould's findings about why it failed to acquire Wind would not bar it from gaining a remedy for its claims. Catalyst argued that, even accepting Justice Newbould's findings, it was nonetheless entitled to recovery. Justice Tulloch rejected this submission. In its argument, Catalyst, relying on certain statements in Cadbury Schweppes that establish that the court has jurisdiction to grant a remedy dictated by the facts of the case rather than strict doctrinal considerations, argued that it may be entitled to equitable remedies such as an accounting of profits even if it suffered no financial loss. However, Justice Tulloch observed that the jurisprudence is clear that a claimant must prove detriment to establish liability for breach of confidence. There is no contradiction between this requirement to prove detriment and the passages from Cadbury Schweppes that Catalyst points to. Accordingly, Justice Newbould findings would bar Catalyst from establishing the liability of West Face, Globalive, and the US Investors for breach of confidence.[86]

Moreover, Justice Tulloch did not place weight on the availability of alternative remedies. Catalyst did not plead any of the alternative remedies such as an accounting for profits that it now referred to on appeal. Instead, it repeatedly pled that the breach of confidence and inducement of breach of contract caused it to fail to acquire Wind. This was a precise inconsistency with Justice Newbould's findings. In the present case, the motions judge correctly identified that the need to prove detriment, namely that the respondents' conduct caused Catalyst to fail to acquire Wind, was a material fact common to the relevant causes of action Catalyst asserted in both actions.[87]
In Seyedi v. Nexen Inc.,[88] the following issue was raised on this appeal: (a) Can misappropriation be established where Nexen made no use of the Plan after Seyedi's departure?[89]

The appellant was an experienced foreign-trained engineer who participated in the Alberta Human Services' program to provide him with Canadian engineering experience. The program was administered by the Calgary Catholic Immigration Society. A letter of understanding was entered into between CCIS, Seyedi and the Respondent Nexen pursuant to which Seyedi served a three-month unpaid practicum with Nexen. At the conclusion of that practicum, Nexen did not offer employment to Seyedi as he had hoped. He then sued Nexen claiming misappropriation of certain intellectual property he had provided to it, aimed at solving a certain environmental problem. Nexen counterclaimed, asserting that Seyedi had misappropriated confidential information when he departed at the end of his practicum.[90]

Nexen called no evidence at trial. Seyedi called, in addition to testifying himself, two witnesses, both Nexen employees, notwithstanding the trial judge's repeated warnings about the risks of calling witnesses allied with Nexen as part of his own case. Both of these witnesses denied that Nexen used his Plan at any time. It had identified and adopted another approach to solving the problem to which the Plan was directed. Seyedi unsuccessfully attempted to convince the judge otherwise, although he led no other direct evidence on this point. Seyedi admitted to having no personal knowledge to the contrary during his own testimony, also admitting that, upon his departure from Nexen, he took Nexen documents without consent.[91]

In dismissing his claim, the trial judge held that Seyedi's unpaid practicum constituted “employment”, with the result that the Plan developed while with Nexen belonged to it. In any event, the Plan was not unique to him as the same concept had been examined and rejected twice previously by Nexen. Most importantly, Seyedi had not proven that Nexen used the Plan, or any intellectual property that he had developed.[92]

Misappropriation of information obtained in confidence creates a cause of action only where the respondent makes use of that property. As observed in the decision under appeal, in International Corona Resources Ltd. v. LAC Minerals Ltd., [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574 (S.C.C.) at 635 La Forest J stated:

The test for whether there has been a breach of confidence … consists in establishing three elements: that the information conveyed was confidential, that it was communicated in confidence and that it was misused by the party to whom it was communicated.[93]

The uncontroverted evidence at trial was that Nexen had made no use of the Plan after his departure and had no intention to do so in the future. Seyedi himself had no personal knowledge of what Nexen did or did not do with this information after his departure. In particular, the uncontroverted evidence from the two witnesses called by Seyedi was that Nexen had never implemented the Plan. The trial judge refused to draw inferences that these witnesses were lying from coincidental timing concerns, innuendo and suspicion raised by Seyedi, including inferences that the dates on certain Nexen documents were wrong based on gas pricing information contained in them. Seyedi failed to show that the trial judge was clearly wrong in failing to draw these inferences based on what was, at best, a thin, speculative argument.[94]

Indeed, the evidence he himself led shows he wanted Nexen to use his idea; the whole purpose of his suggestion of an alternate process to solve an upgrader problem was that Nexen would adopt the process. It did not. His claim was not, at heart, that Nexen should not have used his idea; it was that Nexen should have used his idea and compensated him for it. There was no basis in the evidence or law to impose such obligations on Nexen.[95]
Seyedi had not established that the trial judge made a palpable and overriding error in finding that no such misappropriation occurred.[96]

A claim for damages by the plaintiff arising from the alleged misuse of confidential business information by the defendants was dismissed in Seaway Marine Services Ltd. v. Weiwaikum General Partner Ltd.[97] The case concerned the ownership and operation of a marine fuel barge docked at a marina. The fuel barge and associated equipment was owned by Esso for several years. Esso decided to divest itself of all marine fuel dock operations on the British Columbia coast. The plaintiff was notified of Esso's intention to not renew their dealership agreement. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiff expressed an interest to Esso in buying the fuel barge and associated equipment from Esso, and assuming Esso's lease. The Weiwaikum board assumed management of certain marina-related assets, including the Esso lease which was soon coming to an end. The Weiwaikum board sent letters requesting various items of information related to the lease to Esso and to the plaintiff concerning the lease and the marine fuel operation.
