It received representations from the plaintiff in support of the plaintiff's plan to purchase the fuel barge and assume the lease. The plaintiff's reply to Weiwaikum enclosed a “Letter of Intent” indicating that the plaintiff was in the midst of negotiations with Esso to purchase the fuel barge and with Devco to assume Esso's leasehold. Weiwaikum ultimately decided that the Limited Partnership would purchase the fuel barge from Esso.[98]

The plaintiff alleged that the defendants breached confidence in relation to the information the plaintiff communicated, including reports on the condition and value of the fuel barge; the plaintiff's financial statements; and an outline of the plaintiff's operational plan for the marine fuel business. The trial judge observed that equity is “quick to protect confidences” and sets a “relatively low threshold” on the type of information capable of providing the foundation for a breach of confidence claim. The trial judge had no difficulty in concluding that the information as to the barge condition and value, the information in the financial statements, and the aspects of the “operational plan” was confidential information and accepted on that basis by Weiwaikum. The plaintiff's documents were manifestly confidential. The information in them would have been known to very few outside of the plaintiff, was acquired by the expenditure of the plaintiff's money or its effort, and could not be easily acquired or duplicated by others. The defendants received the information from business letters exchanged during the course of commercial negotiations. The reasonable person standing in the shoes of the defendants would have realized on reasonable grounds that the information was being given by the plaintiff in confidence, and the equitable duty of confidence was therefore imposed.[99]

In the course of the exchange of letters, Weiwaikum stated that it was in the process of reviewing the various options available to it relating to the fuel facility. The plaintiff argued that it was objectively reasonable for its representatives to think that the word “options” related to lease options in relation to the plaintiff and that the option of the defendants choosing to run the business was not “reasonably in prospect”. The trial judge did not accept that the language in the letter should be read down so as to include only options that would involve the plaintiff's ongoing participation in the marine fuel business. The plaintiff must be taken to have known that one of Weiwaikum's options would be to negotiate to buy the barge. The trial judge observed that what the plaintiff knew, or a reasonable person in the plaintiff's position must be taken to have known, was important only insofar as it informed what Weiwaikum, as the recipient of the information, knew or must be taken to have known when it came into receipt of the confidential information. There was no reason for Weiwaikum to be fixed with the knowledge that the plaintiff was sending the confidential barge information on the basis that Weiwaikum would only use it to consider business options that involved the plaintiff. Weiwaikum was entitled to use the confidential barge information it received from Seaway to consider its various options, including the option of a Band entity purchasing the fuel barge and running the business without the plaintiff's involvement.[100]

The trial judge was also inclined to find that the use of the financial statements for purposes other than determining whether the plaintiff was a viable tenant was unauthorized, absent other considerations. However, the plaintiff replied to the defendant's letter of request by stating that it was more than capable of assuming the financial commitments of the current lease, and that it was willing to forward the financial statements if necessary and it is demonstrated that this is a standard requirement of all lessees or assignees. The response from Weiwaikum spoke of confirming the financial status of the plaintiff and stated that requiring the financial statements of prospective lessees or assignees is common practice. This response, and the language used by the plaintiff in its letter enclosing the financial statements would lead a reasonable recipient of the financial statements to the conclusion that they were to be used for the purpose of deciding whether the plaintiff would be a viable tenant and not otherwise.[101]

The trial judge reached the same conclusion with regard to the confidential aspects of the “operational plan.” The Weiwaikum request was specific: “In order for the Landlord to consider your request for a ten year lease, we will need to receive a business plan from you outlining your plans for the use and operation of the Fuel Facility.” The plaintiff's response was that no business plan was needed as the plan was to sell fuel for ten years plus any optional years. Weiwaikum replied that if the plaintiff was interested in a new lease, Weiwaikum required a business plan as part of its due diligence. The plaintiff then sent the one-page “operational plan” alongside a reiteration of its position that it was seeking an assignment of the existing lease rather than a new lease. The trial judge concluded that this exchange of correspondence would lead a reasonable recipient of the confidential aspects of the plaintiff's “operational plan” to conclude that the permitted use was in connection with deciding whether the plaintiff would be a viable tenant and not otherwise.[102]

The trial judge's conclusion that the defendants were entitled to use the plaintiff's barge information when considering all of the various options for the fuel dock narrowed the issue to whether the defendants made use of the financial statements or confidential aspects of the “operational plan” for purposes other than assessing the viability of the plaintiff as a tenant. Briefing notes prepared for a meeting with Chief Pollard included a reference to information from figures extracted from the plaintiff's 2005 income statement and reflected use of the financial statements for an unauthorized purpose. The use of the information in the financial statements as part of a briefing note for a meeting to consider whether the Limited Partnership should take over the marine fuel dock was not a permitted use of this confidential information. The question whether the information was actually factored in to the decision to purchase and run the fuel barge was another matter. The trial judge considered it unlikely that there was substantive discussion at this brief meeting on the question of whether the Limited Partnership should take over the fuel dock business, and highly unlikely that any use was made during this meeting of the plaintiff's 2005 financial figures.[103]

The plaintiff argued that the timing of a meeting by the Weiwaikum board and Chief Pollard with Esso representatives, occurring just a few days after Weiwaikum received confidential information from the plaintiff, together with the exclusion of the plaintiff from the meeting, was powerful evidence in support of its case. The trial judge concluded that this meeting was scheduled at the instance of Esso. Esso had the date in mind before the plaintiff's letter was written. There was nothing on Esso's agenda that called for the plaintiff's attendance. It was fair to characterize Esso's agenda as that of a tenant meeting with its landlord in advance of the expiry of its lease. There certainly was some discussion during the meeting of the terms on which Esso might deal with Weiwaikum, but there was no support for the notion that Weiwaikum or Chief Pollard made use of Seaway's financial statements or “operational plan”.[104]

The plaintiff alleged that during the period from the date that Weiwaikum received the plaintiff's confidential information until the date of purchase of the fuel barge from Esso, Weiwaikum and the Band used the confidential information to assess the risk in deciding to take over the fuel dock. The trial judge concluded that there was no evidence that pointed to the conclusion that the defendants likely made use of the financial statements or confidential aspects of the operational plan in coming to their decisions to buy the barge and run the marine fuel business.[105]

The only misuse of confidential information demonstrated was very limited, namely, the inclusion of data from the 2005 financial statements in the Weiwaikum briefing note. There was no evidence that the very limited misuse of the confidential information played any part in the decision taken to acquire the fuel barge and operate the marine fuel business. The plaintiff was in no different position than it would have been in had the misuse not occurred. The plaintiff failed to prove damages on a “common sense view of causation.[106]

The plaintiff was not entitled to compensatory damages for the defendants' misuse of confidential information despite the submission that this result was foreclosed by the necessary imposition on the defendants of a “special disability in the field of competition”. The trial judge understood the plaintiff's argument to be that this “special disability” was imposed regardless of the nature and extent of the misuse of confidential information. The trial judge observed that the difficulty with this argument was that it lost sight of the relationship between the concept of “special disability” and the concept of using information as a “spring-board” to get an “unfair start”; stating:

It is not every misuse of confidential information, regardless of how limited or trifling, that triggers the application of the “special disability.” In the case at bar the defendants did not make use of the information as a “spring-board for activities detrimental to the person who made the confidential communication” so there is no question of obtaining an unfair start and no basis for finding that the defendants were specially disabled from acquiring the marine fuel business in these particular circumstances.

In Aram Systems Ltd. v. NovAtel Inc., 2008 ABQB 441 (Alta. Q.B.), aff'd 2009 ABCA 262 (Alta. C.A.), MacLeod J. wrote, at para. 105, that regardless of how the breach of confidence obligation is characterized, “the Court's concern is with enforcing the reasonable expectations of the parties in the particular commercial context.” From this narrow perspective, it cannot be seriously contended that it would have been within the expectation of Seaway or the defendants that the mere receipt or trifling misuse of the confidential information would result in the defendants being cleared from the field of competition for the marine fuel business.

Moreover, there is a broader perspective to consider. While there is no question of the importance of the policy of the law that confidences are to be respected, to impose the competitive disability on the defendants advocated for by Seaway in the absence of a finding that the defendants made use of the information as a “spring-board” would be inconsistent with the strong public interest in the maintenance of commercial competition spoken of by Smith J.A. in Expert Travel Financial Security (E.T.F.S.) Inc. v. BMS Harris & Dixon Insurance Brokers Ltd., 2005 BCCA 5 (B.C. C.A.) at para. 79. The proper balance between the policy of the law that encourages competition and the policy of the law that protects commercial confidences would be upset by finding that the defendants were uniquely disabled from acquiring the fuel barge business in circumstances where the confidential information played no role in its acquisition.[107]

The trial judge observed that the result should not differ between a case where information is in fact “nothing very special” and a case where information may have value but is treated by the recipient as if it was “nothing very special”. The trial judge concluded that the plaintiff's claim failed because the limited misuse of the confidential information by Weiwaikum made no difference to the plaintiff's position. The breach of confidence was not sufficiently serious that the Court should invoke its equitable discretion to award damages.[108]

In ThyssenKrupp Elevator (Canada) Ltd. v. Amos,[109] the court had an opportunity to consider the question of how the classic “trial model” response to a motion for summary judgment is affected in a breach of confidence case by the “culture shift” mandated by the Supreme Court of Canada in Combined Air Mechanical Services Inc. v. Flesch, 2014 SCC 7 (S.C.C.).

The plaintiff alleged that the defendant was induced to leave its employ to take up a position with the corporate defendants. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated the non-competition, non-solicitation and confidentiality clauses of his employment contract, a separate confidentiality agreement, and his fiduciary duties. The defendants sought summary judgment on the basis that that plaintiff had no firsthand evidence of illicit solicitation of customers or misuse of confidential information. The plaintiff responded that the evidence of what the defendants did to solicit customers of the plaintiff was uniquely within the knowledge of the defendants. On that basis, the plaintiff suggested that it was entitled to documentary discovery and examinations for discovery in order to compel the defendants to provide the necessary evidence. The court could infer that there were material issues of fact requiring a trial by extrapolating or “following the dots” from the limited evidence that the plaintiffs had obtained.[110]

The court observed that it remains the obligation of parties responding to a motion for summary judgment to “put their best foot forward” or to “lead trump or risk losing”. The defendant expressly denied releasing confidential information to his new employer. The plaintiff could have sought directions to compel the defendants to produce their affidavits of documents prior to the hearing of the motion. It did not seek the right to conduct examinations for discovery or take steps to schedule other examinations. It also did not produce its own affidavit of documents. Under the roadmap provided in Hryniak, counsel can no longer just point to a contested issue of fact to then consign the parties to the slowest and most expensive outcome under the “trial model”. The motion judge observed:

… Here, it is not hard to imagine the existence of some documents that could help the plaintiff's case. One can never dismiss peoples' propensity to write emails that contain information that is harmful to their own legal interests. It would not be hard to imagine someone emailing Mr. Amos to ask if he thinks a potential client would like this or that—with Mr. Amos then drawing upon his experience with the client to respond potentially in breach of his confidentiality obligations whether intentionally so or not.

Where does an issue of fishing for production come into play in the Hryniak roadmap? The question is not one for drawing inferences on the facts or assessing credibility. I do not need to hear from the plaintiff as it has no evidence. Mr. Amos has already been cross-examined and I have read the full transcript. I do not need him again. The question is whether to order production of documents, perhaps even limited production of documents, so as to give the plaintiff (and the Court) a better assurance that there is no smoking gun in circumstances where despite the lack of evidence, a degree of suspicion is reasonable.

The motions judge concluded that it can no longer suffice to put parties to the cost and imposition of litigation based on the default position of the trial model being fairer. The plaintiff, faced with several avenues to seek production from the defendants to respond to the motion for summary judgment chose to limit its investigations and just ask for the motion to be dismissed so the parties could go to discovery. The action should be dismissed. The plaintiff had not brought forward evidence to raise a material issue of fact require a trial. To allow some discovery of documents would be tantamount to a fishing expedition. The motions judge was able to fairly and justly adjudicate the dispute and defaulting to the “trial model” by ordering discovery was not a timely, affordable or proportionate procedure.[111]

Not every case where summary judgment is sought is appropriate for summary determination. Although a motion judge is required to assume that the parties have, in fact, placed before the court all of the evidence necessary for the judge to be able to confidently resolve the dispute, summary judgment should be denied where it is clear to the judge that there is material evidence that should be before the court but is not. In Hamilton v. Desert Lake Family Resort Inc.,[112] the plaintiffs' claims were grounded in contract. The counterclaim sought damages for breach of confidence. The defence position on the main action was that there were multiple triable issues and that the most just and proportionate means of resolving the dispute between the parties was by way of a trial, conducted in accordance with the simplified procedure. Alternatively, the defence argued that if summary judgment was to be granted, the plaintiffs' action should be dismissed and the defendant should have judgment on its counterclaim for breach of confidence. The motions judge declined to grant summary judgment.[113]

The plaintiffs were two couples. The Hamiltons and the Wilsons each owned trailers which they purchased from the defendant. The defendant owned and operated a family campground property and also operated as a dealer of trailers. From the time they were purchased, until 2015, the plaintiffs' trailers were located on what were described as premium waterfront lots at the defendant's resort. The plaintiffs' dealings, in the course of their respective discussions which led to the purchase of their trailers, were with Brett Coleman. In February 2013, the Pillays purchased the shares in the resort from the Colemans. In 2014 and 2015, there were some discussions between Hamilton and the Pillays towards a possible acquisition to purchase a majority of the shares in the resort. Those negotiations eventually broke down and, shortly afterwards, the relationship between the Hamiltons and the Pillays became acrimonious. The interests of the Wilsons were largely aligned with those of the Hamiltons. The Hamiltons were advised that their licence to occupy the waterfront site which their trailer was located on would not be renewed upon its expiry in October 2015. The Hamiltons were also informed that the defendant did not recognize the so-called “resale guarantee” which the plaintiffs claimed was a critical factor in their decision to purchase the trailers. The Wilsons left the resort around the same time as the Hamiltons, believing that they, too, would not be able to enforce the guarantee which they believed they had been given.[114]

The evidence of Pillay was that, in July 2013, she was told by Brett Coleman that no commitments or promises had been made by him to anyone about selling their trailers on waterfront lots. However, when, following the commencement of the action, the Pillays commenced third party proceedings against the Colemans, the Colemans delivered a third party defence in which they pleaded that the agreements for the purchase of the trailers by the Hamiltons and the Wilsons expressly guaranteed that the trailers could be sold on-site. The third party action had since been resolved. A term of the settlement of that action precluded the Colemans from discussing with other parties, including the plaintiffs, the matters in dispute in the main action.[115]

The motion judge observed that the absence of any evidence from Brett Coleman was troubling. The counterclaim was just as problematic. The basis for the counterclaim for breach of confidence was the alleged dissemination by Hamilton of confidential financial information which he obtained from the defendant during the course of his negotiations to purchase an interest in the defendant corporation. There was also an allegation that Hamilton misused this confidential information for purposes unconnected with the possible purchase of shares. This occurred when a company, incorporated by Hamilton for the purpose, attempted to take an assignment from the Colemans of a vendor take back mortgage on the resort. With respect to the counterclaim, it was difficult to assess whether it was more than merely tactical. Suffice it to say that it was not totally devoid of merit, but even if the motion judge were to find that there was a valid claim, no evidence had been adduced which would enable the Court to assess the extent to which, if at all, the defendant had suffered damages. The motion judge did not rule out the possibility that deploying the court's fact finding powers under r. 20.04(2.1) might be sufficient to fill the evidentiary gaps but it was also possible that a tailored trial procedure employing some of the directions and terms set out in r. 20.05(2) could provide an equally efficient and, possibly, fairer process. The parties were therefore invited to confer and consider their respective positions on the most efficient way to move forward, following which the parties should attend a directions hearing.[116]

In Duncan Sabine Collyer Partners LLP v. Campbell,[117] the personal defendant became an employee of the plaintiff on January 1st, 2005. The personal defendant at no held a partnership or equity position in the plaintiff. It appeared that the personal defendant was in practical terms running the firm's branch. There was no direct evidence of the personal defendant's utilization of such things as the revenues and pricing structures of the plaintiff for his own or others financial benefit. The plaintiff made a very general allegation in its pleading: “He used our confidential information in relation to our customer lists and his knowledge of our clients.”[118] The defendant was clear in his absolute denial of using pricing, client lists or other records. The plaintiff was not able to give one specific example of a former client being persuaded to utilize Campbell's firm by his actual breach of his fiduciary duty to his former employer. In addition, the court had no evidence showing that the defendants used the plaintiff's confidential information in such a fashion to benefit themselves financially or to harm the reputation or profitability of the plaintiff. The court was left with a “he said” or “she said” scenario without reference to one single client conversion. There appeared to have been no effort on the plaintiff's part to cross-index and check its own client list at sale against the acquired business clients the next year by BDO. An investigation or questioning of at least some of these “missing” clients as to why they did not take their accounting business to BDO would perhaps have provided at least one example of client conversion and the relevant reasons why. While the plaintiff's case was plausible and defendable in theory, there was no evidence available for consideration on the motion which would defeat the defendants' motion for summary judgment. The defendants had by pointing out the lack of evidence concerning their alleged fiduciary breach, shifted the onus to the plaintiff. The plaintiff simply had no evidence in this area to defeat the defendants.[119]

In terms of the obligation of all employees not to misuse confidential information of the former employer, the courts have held that trade secrets and customer lists are confidential. However, there is some ambiguity as to whether “confidential information” includes the names of such customers, and their needs and preferences, that the employee has learned during his period of service and can recall. In Parrish & Heimbecker Ltd. v. Delmar Commodities Ltd.,[120] the plaintiff sought from both Hodgson and Delmar return of its confidential information and an injunction enjoining them from using such confidential information or soliciting its customers, particularly in an area of Manitoba described as the “northeast territory”. The defendant Hodgson was employed by the plaintiff until September 6, 2011 when he went to work for Delmar, a supplier and competitor of the plaintiff. In the winter of 2010/11, Delmar decided that because the plaintiff had chosen not to extend its reach into the northeast territory with a facility in the area, it would do so. It entered into an agreement to acquire land and engaged local contractors to do the construction work. Delmar did not advise the plaintiff of its intention to build this facility until after Hodgson had joined the company. On September 6, 2011, Hodgson resigned from his employment with the plaintiff. He had sought out other employment and as a result secured two offers, one from Delmar for the position of Territory Manager for Eastern Manitoba. He took the job and began work shortly thereafter. Hodgson denied that he took any customer list or other property of the plaintiff when he left its employ. The plaintiff had no evidence that he took any such documentation. There was no formal employment contract between Hodgson and the plaintiff, although he did endorse his acknowledgement on the plaintiff's employee handbook which contained a provision obliging all employees to maintain in strict confidence information received by the plaintiff or its customers and requiring them not to disclose this information either during the period of employment or at any time thereafter.[121]

The motions judge observed that there was limited, if any, evidence of Hodgson having or using confidential information of the plaintiff. There was no evidence that he had any documentation belonging to the plaintiff, including customer lists. He had no secret information about pricing of Legend Seed, as all sellers were required to sell at the same price. There was no evidence that he had targeted the plaintiff's customers. The names of all farmers in the area were public information.[122]

It was possible that, at trial, Hodgson would not be found to have been a key employee. However, the evidence was quite convincing that he was. As General Manager, he was more than a sales manager. He had general managerial responsibilities over a large facility with a substantial sales volume. In terms of his reassignment to Customer Service Manager, he held this position for only the last two or three months of his employment with the plaintiff. In both positions, he acquired considerable knowledge about the plaintiff's customers.[123] If Hodgson did no more than pass on his business card and advise of where he was working, it was possible that, at trial, this might be found not to constitute solicitation. However, this seemed unlikely. By personally attending at the farms, Hodgson had clearly done more than generally advertise his new employment. He directly approached farmers, knowing that some of them were customers of the plaintiff, in an attempt to secure their business. And he has successfully concluded sales with some of these individuals.

However, the plaintiff had not established that it would suffer irreparable harm if the injunction were denied. The court was not persuaded that the plaintiff's customers were moving to Delmar because of any solicitation on the part of Hodgson. Instead, any loss of market share would appear to result from Delmar now selling Legend Seed and having a facility in the area and, probably even more importantly, from the plaintiff's decision to no longer sell Legend Seed.

The balance of convenience weighed in favour of denying an injunction. The reality was that the sale of soybean seeds was a highly competitive business. While Delmar hired Hodgson to assist in its entry into the northeast territory market, there was scant evidence that it or Hodgson was using confidential information or targeting the plaintiff's customers. Further, even if Hodgson was a key employee of the plaintiff, the law provides that he could join a competitor, sell to its customers, and advertise.[124]

In the Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co. case,[125] the court held that the defendant, Leeson, had not disclosed to his new employer, Home Oil, any information he may have known about Chevron's (his former employer's) exploration and testing for oil, and so had not breached his obligation of confidence. The court held that the suspicion of misuse of confidential information is insufficient to impose liability; there must be real evidence of misuse of the plaintiff's confidential business information.

It is important to bear in mind that the efficacy of ethical walls is a question of fact. In Dataco Utility Services Ltd. v. Olameter Inc.,[126] a purchase transaction did not proceed and the defendant was successful in outbidding the plaintiff for a contract with a corporation that had been the major client of the plaintiff. During the RFP process for that contract, a memorandum entitled “Ethical Wall Procedures” was circulated to various employees of the defendant. That memorandum stated that the defendant intended “to adopt procedures to ensure that no information that may be confidential to the plaintiff that was obtained as a result of prior discussions was used in any way in connection with the defendant's bid.” The trial judge observed that, while they are by no means a panacea, it would be wrong to hold that measures such as ethical walls are never effective or that they must be in place by a designated time in order to be effective. Each case must be decided on its own facts.[127]

In Geophysical Service Inc. v. Nwest Energy Corp.,[128] the plaintiff brought a motion to amend its statement of claim to revise its original claim against the defendants, add three new named defendants, and add 26 “John Doe” style defendants. The claim was originally for $1,951,811.50, and the plaintiff now wanted to increase the claim to $13,658,816.00, plus advance a claim for a licence fee of $3,414,704.00 for each instance where the Defendants or other third parties disclosed the plaintiff's seismic data in whole or in part, to any other third party. The plaintiff licensed seismic data to a customer and alleged that the seismic data, or derivatives of it, had been improperly shared. Initially it sued two parties. The Court allowed the amendment to add one of the new parties, but dismissed the application to add the rest.[129]

The claim had its genesis in the supply of seismic data by the plaintiff to NWest, with which GSI had a contract, called the MSDL Agreement. The MSDL Agreement required NWest to keep the information confidential and not share it with other parties except in accordance with specific terms prescribed under the MSDL Agreement. GSI alleged that the seismic data made its way to other energy companies but GSI did not know who they are, what exactly was shared with them if anything, exactly when that occurred or how or what if anything they did with it. It suspects that these other companies at least saw either the seismic data or at least material setting out derivatives of the data, perhaps in a PowerPoint presentation, perhaps in a thumb drive, perhaps in the DropBox software format, perhaps in some other way, if they did not actually receive a copy of the raw seismic data.[130]

The claims for breach of confidence and copyright infringement proceed from the premise that the simple receipt of information, either confidential information or copyright material, creates a liability to the owner of the confidential information or the copyright work, even if the recipient was unaware of the confidentiality claim or the copyright by the owner. Regarding an actionable claim for breach of confidence, it cannot be the law that simple receipt creates liability. Otherwise, in regards to the possession of confidential information, when an employee who has confidential information leaves the job (quits or is dismissed by the employer) and finds work at another employer in the same industry there is automatically a valid claim against him, and probably against his new employer, regardless of whether he or she makes any use of the confidential information, because the now former employee of the claimant has confidential information in his or her mind and works for a competitor. That would have the effect of sterilizing the former employee from working in the same industry. The actionable wrong is the breach of confidence, using or disclosing the information without the consent of the person to whom the duty is owed. The person who receives it innocently has no liability until either he actually learns of the impropriety, or there is a constructive notice of impropriety. The “constructive notice” that was put forward was that the recipients of the seismic data must have known that it was confidential “given the valuable nature of seismic data”. However, there was nothing to indicate that they would have, or should have, known that it was confidential to someone other than NWest who was allegedly sharing it with them. Where Party A gives confidential information to Party B but party B does nothing with it, there is no breach. Similarly, where party A gives information to Party B, who improperly shares it with Party C who is unaware of Party A's claim over it, and Party C does not make use of it, Party C has neither received the information with any obligation to Party A, nor has it breached the confidence. Party B has breached the confidence, and may be liable to Party A, but there may or may not be any damages, since Party C did nothing with it.[131]

GSI could not show that any other party had actually made use of the West Newfoundland Materials that may have been improperly disclosed but they might have used it by choosing to do nothing—that is, by not getting involved in an energy investment. As a result, GSI wanted to add these unknown parties in hopes that it could establish that they made use of the West Newfoundland Materials by not doing anything with them, and therefore not making a profit and not earning any ill-gotten gains that should be partly disgorged to GSI as licence fees. GSI allegedly suffered damages because it lost the ability to licence the information directly to those third parties so that they could, after paying GSI a licence fee, conclude that there was no good investment to be made. The court observed that there is a question whether non-action could amount to use. If it were accepted that a failure to act could be an actionable use it would be necessary for a claimant to demonstrate that the defendant had set upon a particular course of conduct from which they subsequently withdrew. There was no evidence of any of the unidentified companies withdrawing from any course of conduct. There was only evidence of a suspicion that they may have chosen not to embark on a course of conduct at all after viewing the West Newfoundland Materials. There was no evidence that those third parties knew that the data was owned by GSI, and no evidence other than that they may have seen it—not that a decision of any meaningful kind was made by the third parties. The recipient or recipients, if they actually received the seismic data or some derivative of it, may have simply decided to invest elsewhere, or not at all, without making any analysis of the GSI seismic data.[132]

In order to meet even the very low “modest evidence” standard for amendments, there must be some evidence of either knowledge, or at least constructive knowledge, of the confidential claim by GSI and improper use. All of these elements were missing from the evidence. It was suggested that the data was disseminated to one or more of 26 unknown parties, in a manner not known, at a time not known, based on a claim that is, from the outset, largely based on a faulty legal premise. And as well there was no evidence that any of these unknown parties did anything with the data if they received it. With this dearth of evidence the plaintiff wanted to significantly re-cast the claim. There was no evidence here that any of the 26 in this group did anything that would give rise to a cause of action. The amendment was sought because someone is this group might have done something that gave rise to a claim by GSI.[133] There would be serious prejudice to NWest, whose entire business activities were on hold because the case has already crippled its ability to carry on, if all 29 or 30 defendants were added. Such an amendment would significantly re-cast the claim. These proposed amendments were hopeless because they proceeded on a faulty legal premise and because there was no evidence of wrongdoing, just suspicion.[134]

In Geophysical Service Incorporated v. Murphy Oil Company Ltd.,[135] the Defendant was one of many companies that GSI sued for the improper use of its seismic materials. The Plaintiff claimed damages from the Defendant for breach of contract, breach of copyright, breach of confidence, conversion, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation and interference with GSI's contractual relations with others. The Defendant had an interest in several oil and gas fields off the east coast of Canada. In 2008 it withdrew from offshore Nova Scotia and the Laurentian Basin but continued to have working interests in the Hibernia and Terra Nova fields, which are in offshore Newfoundland. Murphy partnered with others on these projects, most of whom also licensed seismic data from the Plaintiff. Issues common to them were tried first in Geophysical Service Inc. v. Encana Corp., 2016 CarswellAlta 742, 2016 ABQB 230, affd 2017 CarswellAlta 732, 2017 ABCA 125, leave to appeal refused 2017 CarswellAlta 2545 (S.C.C.). The decision determined that copying and accessing seismic data from government sources, including the Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Offshore Petroleum Board and the Canada-Nova Scotia Offshore Petroleum Board between October 1995 and April 1998 without paying GSI a license fee, was permissible.[136]

The Plaintiff and the Defendant entered into three agreements: the 1996 Agreement, the 1999 Agreement and the 2000 MDLA. From time to time, they also entered into supplemental agreements pursuant to which the Plaintiff licensed additional seismic data to the Defendant. Sometimes the Plaintiff simply sent the Defendant an invoice for seismic data. One of the primary submissions advanced by the Plaintiff was that all seismic data, regardless of when or how it was licensed, was subject to the 2000 MDLA. The Defendant's contention was that retroactively imposing the terms and conditions of the 2000 MDLA onto the 1996 Agreement and the 1999 Agreement and to events that pre-dated the 2000 MDLA was inconsistent with the terms of the 2000 MDLA. The Defendant succeeded in its application for summary dismissal. The chambers judge dismissed the Plaintiff's claim because there were no issues of merit on the record and in the pleadings that genuinely required a trial: Geophysical Service Incorporated v. Murphy Oil Company Ltd.[137]

On appeal, the Plaintiff submitted that the chambers judge erred by dismissing the claim for breach of confidence. A close examination of the Statement of Claim reveals that the only material that could be the subject of the claims for conversion, breach of confidence and breach of contract was the seismic data that was licensed to the Defendant under the 2000 MDLA; in other words, the Agreement Materials. The Accessed Materials were excluded because as the chambers judge reasonably concluded the Defendant was entitled to access them pursuant to the Common Issues Decision. The Additional Materials could not be the subject of the Remaining Claims because that term, as defined and used in the Statement of Claim, meant Seismic Materials obtained by the Defendant from third party corporations and Exploration Partners but not from the Plaintiff. Given the finding that the Plaintiff had no Additional Materials, there could be no Remaining Claims based on these materials. This left the “Agreement Materials”. “Agreement Materials” was defined Seismic Material “licensed by the Defendant under the Agreement. The definition of Agreement was “the Master Seismic Data License Agreement dated November 27, 2000 between the Plaintiff as licensor, and the Defendant as licensee. Accordingly, Agreement Materials were those licensed under the 2000 MDLA and the three supplemental agreements. Further, by specifically defining Agreement Materials this way, the Seismic Materials licensed by the Defendant under both the 1996 and the 1999 Agreements were excluded from all the Remaining Claims.[138]

The claims of conversion, breach of confidence and breach of contract relied upon a common foundation that the Defendant wrongfully shared Agreement Materials. The 1999 Anadarko email was the only direct evidence of the Defendant sharing the Plaintiff's seismic materials with others, and it referred to events in 1998. The Plaintiff effectively contended that it was the proverbial “tip of the iceberg” and knowledge of similar situations was exclusively within the knowledge and possession of the Defendant. At best it the Plaintiff's evidence was that “it would be inconceivable for Murphy … not to have shared seismic data with others” in “data rooms or during presentations for prospective venture participants and purchasers”. The Plaintiff's evidence rested on the “tip of the iceberg” Anadarko email and the speculative statements of Einarsson regarding the Defendant's transactions in 2010, 2011 and 2012. The Court of Appeal explained that there was no way of knowing whether there were other transactions that may have attracted the obligations set out in the 2000 MDLA. When “determining whether there is a genuine issue requiring a trial, the court must decide whether there is an evidentiary basis for a suspicion. At the end of the day, the question was whether the Plaintiff had established a palpable and overriding error in the chambers judge's conclusion that on a balance of probabilities there was no merit to these claims. Apart from the Anadarko email, the bulk of the Plaintiff's case was speculative. This was so despite the disclosure by the Defendant of its records and the Plaintiff's access to the records of all of the other companies it had sued alleging similar misconduct. Given the standard of appellate review, the Court of Appeal was not persuaded that there was a palpable and overriding error in the chambers judge's decision dismissing the claims of conversion, breach of confidence and breach of contract associated with the Agreement Materials.[139]

In breach of confidence cases, the plaintiff ought to specifically identify the information over which it claims a proprietary right, and the circumstances in which knowledge of the information came into the possession of the defendant such that use of the information by the defendant would be unconscionable. In Blue Line Hockey Acquisition Co. v. Orca Bay Hockey Ltd. Partnership,[140] the action concerned the sale of the Vancouver Canucks, General Motors Place and the assets relating to both. Blue Line alleged that Gaglardi, Beedie and Aquilini formed a partnership to pursue the acquisition of an interest in the Enterprise. According to Blue Line, the three partners agreed they would not pursue their objective without the involvement of all partners. It was alleged that under the Partnership, Aquilini owed a fiduciary duty to the other partners to refrain from diverting opportunities to acquire an interest in the Enterprise to himself, and to refrain from using confidential information of the Partnership for his own benefit. The Partnership entered into negotiations with the Orca Bay Defendants in November 2003. Blue Line alleged that Aquilini left the Partnership some months later and secretly pursued the acquisition of an interest in the Enterprise with the Orca Bay Defendants. Blue Line alleged that Aquilini, in the course of his secret negotiations with the Orca Bay Defendants, used confidential information he obtained from the Partnership. Negotiations between Blue Line and the Orca Bay Defendants ended on November 5, 2005. On the same day, some of the Aquilini Defendants entered into the Investment Agreement with some of the Orca Bay Defendants to acquire a 50 per cent interest in the Enterprise.[141]

The Aquilini Defendants applied for an order that Blue Line provide further and better particulars as to the individual items of confidential information obtained by the Partnership which, according to the Amended Statement of Claim, the Aquilini Defendants acquired, and when and from whom each item of confidential information was acquired by the Aquilini Defendants; when, where, and of whom the Aquilini Defendants, according to the Amended Statement of Claim, requested confidential information from other members of the Partnership at the time the Aquilini Defendants left the Partnership, and what individual items of information were provided pursuant to such requests; the individual items of confidential information obtained from the Partnership which, according to the Amended Statement of Claim, the Aquilini Defendants used when negotiating with the Orca Bay Defendants.[142]

The plaintiff argued that they should not required to particularize the constituent parts. Rather, the confidential information was, in essence, the contents of the negotiations as embodied in the various drafts of the Term Sheet and the strategies of Blue Line in respect of them. It was not each individual piece of information that was important but the bargaining positions as a whole and the negotiating strategies behind them.[143]

The motions judge did not accept this submission and concluded that the particulars must delineate both the confidential information allegedly possessed by the Aquilini Defendants and the confidential information allegedly used by them to conclude the Investment Agreement.[144]

The motions judge acknowledged that particularization of the information alleged to be confidential may be more difficult in this case than in many breach of confidence or “trade secret” cases. Nevertheless, at trial the plaintiff would be required to establish more than simply that Aquilini “knew the mind of the purchasing group”. The plaintiff would be required to identify the information that was confidential and establish the proprietary nature of that information. The plaintiff would be required to prove facts establishing that Aquilini received the proprietary information in circumstances requiring that the information remain confidential, or facts from which such an inference can reasonably be drawn. The plaintiff would also be required to establish facts which proved that the Aquilini Defendants used the information for purposes of concluding the Investment Agreement, or facts from which that inference could reasonably be drawn. Accordingly, the plaintiff must identify, by way of particulars, the information it says is confidential information, the circumstances in which the information was conveyed to the Aquilini Defendants, and the confidential information it says the Aquilini Defendants used to acquire its interest in the Enterprise. All aspects of the breach of confidence claim must be amenable to such particularization, and the Aquilini Defendants were entitled to those particulars before trial.[145]

In Endplex Investments Inc. v. Derrydale Golf Course Ltd.,[146] a motion for summary judgment brought by the defendant Derrydale asking that the action by the plaintiff, Endplex be dismissed was granted. Derrydale received an unsolicited offer from Endplex to purchase the property owned by Derrydale. The shareholders of Derrydale decided to sell the East and West portions of Derrydale's property to Endplex for its development purposes and to retain the central portion of the property. Derrydale wanted to retain ownership of the central portion of the property for continued use as a 9-hole executive golf course enabling Endplex to take ownership of the East and West parcels for development.[147]

The agreement with Endplex was conditional upon obtaining the consent of the City of Mississauga Committee of Adjustment to sever the two parcels of Derrydale's property and to permit Derrydale to retain lands which would be redeveloped for the nine-hole golf course. The agreement provided that Endplex would pay the costs of Derrydale's application for severance to the Committee of Adjustment. The agreement also required Derrydale and Endplex to work together in using best efforts to obtain approval for the severance of the property from the Committee of Adjustment. In furtherance of this objective, Derrydale retained a consultant to assist in providing planning advice to Derrydale as owner/applicant. Subsequently Endplex, and Derrydale, appointed the consultant to be responsible for the preparation of severance applications for submission to the City of Mississauga Committee of Adjustment. At the direction of Derrydale and Endplex, the consultant submitted the Applications to the Committee of Adjustment seeking consent to sever the two parcels. Both severances were approved subject to conditions that were to be fulfilled within one year from the date of the decision, namely, by August 12, 2005. The consultant, acting at the direction of both Endplex and Derrydale, retained consultants for the purpose of obtaining expert reports for submission to the Region of Peel, the Committee of Adjustment, the City of Mississauga and the Credit Valley Conservation in order to satisfy the conditions for severance required by the Committee of Adjustment. The conditions required, that a number of technical matters be addressed through the submission of expert reports to be reviewed and approved by the City and Credit Valley Conservation. Thereafter, at the direction of both Derrydale and Endplex, the consultant coordinated the retainer of consultants for the preparation of expert reports required to satisfy the Region of Peel, the City of Mississauga and the Credit Valley Conservation. At the direction of Derrydale and Endplex, and without any constraints on the release of such expert reports, the consultant submitted three expert reports provided to the City of Mississauga and to the Credit Valley Conservation for purposes of satisfying the conditions of the severances established by the Committee of Adjustment. The submission of the expert reports was part of the public approval process provided for under the Planning Act.[148]

At or about the same time as the consultants' reports were being filed with the City of Mississauga and the Credit Valley Conservation, Endplex, entered into discussions with the consultant with respect to potential retainer of Glenn Schnarr and Associates by Endplex to obtain land-use planning approvals related to Endplex's development plans for the West parcel. The consultant gave Endplex an opinion that there was a low prospect for the development for residential uses of the West parcel because of existing land-use planning constraints.[149]

The Agreement of Purchase and Sale provided that if Endplex was not satisfied that the lands could be zoned with a zoning designation satisfactory to it, Endplex had the right to terminate the Agreement to purchase the two parcels of property. Before making its second deposit, Endplex terminated the Agreement of Purchase and Sale and requested the return of its initial deposit pursuant to the terms of the agreement. The initial deposit of $250,000 was returned to Endplex by Derrydale.[150]

Endplex wrote to the consultant and requested all the reports that had been prepared by consultants, including the originals and copies of all reports which were prepared and filed with the City of Mississauga or distributed to any other third party, be collected and turned over to Endplex. Endplex asserted that the reports were the property of Endplex and further that such reports were not to be disseminated or used in any fashion without the consent of Endplex. Endplex's assertion of an entitlement to ownership and possession of all reports was contrary to the provisions of the Agreement of Purchase and Sale. Notwithstanding the Agreement, the consultant collected the reports and forwarded them to Endplex. Derrydale's solicitor, immediately denied Endplex's claim to ownership of the reports prepared by the consultants. The “First” reports were never returned to Derrydale.[151]

After the termination of the agreement by Endplex, Derrydale sought a new purchaser for the two parcels of land. Derrydale entered into an Agreement of Purchase and Sale with GWL for the East parcel. GWL was not interested in purchasing the West parcel. The parcel which is the subject of the agreement between GWL and Derrydale is a slightly modified version of the East parcel that Derrydale had originally agreed to sell to Endplex. As a result, Derrydale and GWL were required to satisfy the conditions of the approved severance relating to the East parcel.[152]

The initial agreement between Derrydale and GWL provided that GWL would not pursue the existing applications for severances and would make a new application for a severance to the Committee of Adjustment notwithstanding that the existing severances for the East and West parcels had already been approved by the Committee of Adjustment subject to conditions. The purpose of this agreement between Derrydale and GWL to make a new application for severance was to accommodate concerns being expressed by Endplex as to its “property” rights in the consultants' reports and the existing severance applications.[153]

The Secretary-Treasurer of the Committee of Adjustment denied a request by Endplex to close or suspend the operation of the approved severance applications, stating that the applications were still active and available to the owner of the property before lapsing on August 12, 2005.[154]

In May of 2005, a number of terms of the GWL Agreement were amended by the parties. One of the terms of the GWL contract, which was amended, was the provision that GWL pursue a new severance application to permit sale by Derrydale of the East parcel. This amendment reflected the fact that the Committee of Adjustment had confirmed that the existing severances and applications were approved, subject to the conditions stipulated, and that such approval could not be withdrawn. Further, the Committee of Adjustment confirmed that Derrydale, as owner of the property, was in a position to satisfy the conditions prior to the severance collapsing on August 12, 2005.[155]

As the conditions for severance of the East parcel had not yet been fulfilled, through its planning consultants GWL retained its own consultants to prepare and file expert reports (hereinafter, the “Second” reports) in order to satisfy the conditions for the severance of the East parcel.[156]

Endplex claimed that it held a copyright interest in the “First” reports generated in support of the applications for severance of the East and West parcels, that it owned such reports and that the defendant Derrydale breached an obligation to hold in confidence and not to use information in relation to the applications for severance. With respect to this latter allegation, it was alleged by the plaintiffs that GWL in their acquisition of the East parcel from Derrydale were provided by Derrydale with copies of various reports, information and documents that were confidential and that this is a breach of the defendant's obligation to the plaintiff.[157]

The plaintiff asserted that, if the defendant Derrydale was not obliged by contract to hold in confidence and not use information in relation to the applications for severance, the obligations were implied terms of the agreement. Justice Murray would not imply such a contractual restriction. Over a month before the termination of the agreement by Endplex, various consultants' reports, the “First” reports were submitted to the City of Mississauga, and to the CVC for purposes of clearing the conditions of the severances. These reports were filed with public authorities to satisfy conditions for severance of the parcels of land which Endplex had agreed to purchase and to be available for public scrutiny in what is a public process. There was no objection by Endplex to the filing of these reports. Even if Endplex held a bona fide belief that Derrydale had an obligation to maintain the confidentiality of the reports, the joint filing of such reports with various public authorities in order to meet the conditions for severance imposed by the Committee of Adjustment was, by necessary implication, a waiver of any claim to confidentiality of those reports by Endplex. Indeed, if Derrydale had prevented the filing of the reports with the authorities, it would have been in breach of the agreement with Endplex to “cooperate in the processing of the applications and the execution of any documents required as part of the application.”[158]

Finally, the “First” reports were not used by the defendant in satisfying the conditions for severance necessary for the sale of the East parcel to GWL. Endplex maintained possession of the “First” reports after it terminated the agreement of purchase and sale. Derrydale did not retain possession of the first reports. After the termination by Endplex of the Agreement of Purchase and Sale, Derrydale neither directly or indirectly employed the “First” reports for any further use or purpose. Such reports were not used for purposes of obtaining the severance of the East parcel for purposes of sale to GWL.[159]

Derrydale had every right to use any information in its possession, including the “First” consultants' reports, to further its application for severance and to achieve its objective of selling the East parcel to GWL. However, at it did not use such information.[160]

Justice Murray concluded that there was no factual or legal basis for the claim by Endplex that Derrydale improperly used confidential information. There were no material facts alleged in any affidavit material filed by the plaintiffs or by the defendant which supported a conclusion that the plaintiff could raise a triable issue in a claim for breach of confidence.[161]

The plaintiff asserted that the misuse of confidential information by Derrydale was also a breach of a fiduciary duty owed by Derrydale to Endplex. As a result, the plaintiff asserted that it was entitled to any profits made by Derrydale including any profits from the sale of the East parcel to GWL. This claim was also completely without foundation. The relationship between the parties was contractual and was terminated when Endplex terminated the Agreement of Purchase and Sale. After the termination of the contract by Endplex, Derrydale had no duty to forsake its own interest to act for the benefit of the plaintiff.[162]
